Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: PETITIONS
text: The economic news-indeed, most of the news-of the nation over the last couple of weeks has been dominated by the fall in the value of the Australian dollar. There can be no doubt that the fall in the value of the Australian dollar which has been recorded over the last several weeks is in part-I stress in part-a direct result of a fall in the level of confidence in the economic management and resolve of the Hawke Government. That decline has taken place not only domestically but also internationally. If we wanted any evidence of why people overseas are now having real doubts as to whether what they previously perceived to be relatively responsible economic policies pursued by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) any longer prevail, we found a very good reason for those doubts in Question Time yesterday and Question Time again today. Yesterday, in answer to a question I put to the Prime Minister, he got up and-I paraphrase the answer he gave-said: 'I agree with you that the economically sensible and rational thing to do is to discount the next national wage case for the effects of the devaluation on the consumer price index. That is the economically responsible thing to do, but I cannot do it because I am bound by the terms of the prices and incomes accord'. That is what the Prime Minister was saying yesterday. He was, in effect, giving official ratification and confirmation to the view that buying industrial peace is more important than the longer term economic health of Australia and is more important than the impact on the .unemployed of Australia of a wage determination system that increasingly this country cannot afford. As the Prime Minister and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) acknowledged yesterday, the depreciation of the Australian dollar of recent weeks, despite the adverse effects of it and despite the fact that it represents some failure or loss of confidence by others in the policies and the assets of this country, confers some competitive gain and edge on our export and import competing industries. The Prime Minister did not dissent from that point of view. However, the important thing is that, if we are not to suffer all the disadinflationary vantages of a depreciation of our currency, we must be willing to insulate our import competing and export industries from the adverse price effects of that depreciation. The only way we can do that is by insulating those industries through the wages system. Increasingly, what is happening, of course, is. that the floating of the Australian dollar has imposed strains upon our wage fixation system and has demonstrated how inappropriate our wage determination system is. Instead of standing up yesterday and saying to the Australian public that the Government would be willing to discount for the effects of the depreciation of the Australian dollar, the Prime Minister rather supinely threw up his arms and said: 'I would like to do it. I know it is the economically responsible thing to do, but I cannot do it because it would break the prices and incomes accord'. What he was doing, as he did over the MX missile issue, was saying that when it comes to a choice between numbers and duty he will choose numbers any time. He has demonstrated that time and again. He demonstrated it over his failure to dismiss the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) from the Cabinet on two occasions; he demonstrated it over the MX missile issue and he is demonstrating it again by his failure to follow the only economically rational cours« in the wake of the depreciation of the Australian dollar. What the Prime Minister knows in his heart and what proper observers of the Australian economic scene know is a reality, and it is a reality that I pointed out in December 1983 when the Government floated the Australian dollar, a decision that I warmly welcomed then and still welcome as one of the very good and praiseworthy decisions that the Hawke Governm«nt has taken. I said on that occasion: Now that the dollar has, quite properly, been floated, the Government can no longer 'fudge' the exchange rate in order to protect it from the consequences of inappropriate and irresponsible domestic fiscal, monetary and wages policies. The dollar float imposes a new discipline on the Government. There is little prospect thilt the industrial wing of the labour movement and the left-wing of the Labor Party will respond to that discipline. If ever we had a demonstration that the Government would not respond to that discipline, we had it yesterday when the Prime Minister was unwilling to give the only economically responsible answer to the question that I asked. It is no wonder that this morning the· Australian Chamber of Commerce, one of the largest business organisations in Australia, had this to say: The business community views with complete bewilderment the Prime Minister's statement that the Federal Government would support the passing on to wages of the effects of the recent decline in the Australian dollar. The statement will only serve to undermine the value of earlier statements by other senior Cabinet Ministers and by the Prime Minister himself on the need to engender business confidence. That is not a bad smack in the eye from the President of the Australian Chamber of Commerce. It is no wonder, because it is an example of the declining domestic confidence in the economic policies of this Government. i have said repeatedly over the past several weeks that there are external reasons for the decline in the value of the dollar. It is not the fault of the present Government or, indeed, any Australian government that these have occurred. I refer, of course, to the strength of the United States dollar and the fact that as a commodity trader we, in common with all other commodity traders, have seen our currency depreciate because of the depressed level of commodity prices. But there one must end the exculpation of the present Government because when one moves to the other set of reasons, one finds that this Government is very much to blame. I and other Opposition members have said repeatedly over the past couple of weeks that the humiliating retreat of the Prime Minister over the MX missile issue has broken in a very significant way the confidence that many people had in him in the economic area. I was told repeatedly by people in the financial community in the United States when I followed the Prime Minister's visit there a couple of weeks ago: 'If he backed down to the left wing in this issue, he will back down to the left wing on other issues'. The decline in the value of the Australian dollar represents a vote of loss of confidence in the leadership of the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and this Government. There is no way that the Government can wriggle and worm out of that because a floating exchange rate tells the story and tells it quickly, plainly and without any kind of fear or favour. That is what makes a floating exchange rate a far better method of running one's exchange rate than other systems.· That is why.a floating exchange rate continues to have the support of the Opposition and, to his credit, the support of the. Treasurer. No doubt he hopes that somehow or other, the realism that a floating exchange rate brings home, will make some of his colleagues aware of many of the difficulties. This loss of confidence in the economic policies of the Government is not something that has arisen only over the last couple of weeks as exemplified by the fall in value of the Australian dollar. One can go back to the Budget of last year. If ever there was an election Budget, if ever there was a Budget designed purely and simply for the polls and hOt for the medium or the longer term, it was the 1984 Budget. It waS a Budget that I described at the time as 'a political document, based on the vote now, pay later principle'. That Budget maximised short term electoral possibilities, but I warned at the time that next year it would present major economic problems on the budgetary front. Of course, those major problems are now becoming apparent. Even in areas where the Government was able in its early months of office to point to some level of success, a slow down is starting to occur. This is happening, for example, in the employment area. Remember how much we were regaled by the GoVernment about the improvements in employment that had taken place since it was elected? Total employment, seasonally adjusted, grew by 3.1 per cent in the 12 months to March 1984, but in the 10 months to January 1984 it has increased at an annual rate of only 1.6 per cent. Real interest rates-that is, the gap between the nominal rate and the rate of inflationare now the highest that they have been for two generations. This Treasurer. not only presided over the highest tax take in Australia's history in the last Budget and the highest level of expenditure in Australia's history in the last Budget, but he also now presides over the highest real interest rates that this country has seen since the end of World War II. No wonder people here and overseas are starting to vote a lack of confidence. Of course, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister are not alone. It amuses me no end to see Labor premiers running around the world inviting foreign banks to establish headquarters in their particular cities. Who else could I think of this week but the Victorian Premier, Mr Cain, who has not' been slow to run around the world inviting this and that bank to establish its headquarters in Melbourne and to a parade all the marvellous advantages of having the headquarters of a bank in Melbourne. There is absolutely nothing wrong with having the headquarters of one's bank in Melbourne. Melbourne is a terrific city. The only thing wrong with it at the moment is its State Government. If ever a person were aligned, in terms of policy attitudes, to those policies of the Federal Government which are now losing favour internationally, it is the Premier of Victoria. Not only has he a sorry record of increases in taxes and charges and of mortgaging the future assets of Victoria's instrumentalities to an unconscionable extent to overseas lenders, but to the Victorian Premier belongs the dubious distinctiqn of being the first political figure in office in the Western world to say that facilities for nuclear-powered vessels would not be available in his port. The Victorian Premier was even two years ahead of the New Zealand Prime Minister in saying that visits by nuclear-powered warships would not be welcome in Victorian ports. I quote from his remarkable statement in 1982, when he declared: , . visits by nuclear-powered or nuclear-armed warships to Victoria from any country are not welcome. Everybody remembers that, fortunately, that exercise in anti-Americanism by the present Victorian Premier was very smartly put down by the then Prime Minister, MalColm Fraser. It is very interesting that as far as Mr Cain's ideology and his attitudes are concerned, he was even two years ahead of the New Zealand Prime Minister. That gives us an idea of the nature, the calibre and the quality of the leadership of that Government. I realise, Madam Deputy Speaker, that I digress a little from my comments on the management of the national economy, but the point must still be made that the economic policies that I condemn, the economic policies that have eroded international confidence in the Australian dollar, are fully supported by that same Premier who led the break out at the 1983 Premiers Conference, where at the last minute the Treasurer got rolled and had to give another $400m in funds to the States. The last two weeks· has seen the coming together of various strands which indicate a loss of confidence in the economic management of this Government. It faces an horrendous problem on the wages front. Not only has it a wage indexation system that this country cannot afford, but the secretary. of the Australian Council of Trade Unions has said that this country has the most beneficial wage fixation system for the trade union movement of any country in the world. On the wages front, the Government also faces the difficulty of what to do with the productivity case. It faces the problem,of putting together a Budget in 1985 when it will have to pay the price of its electoral vote-buying Budget of 1984 and in many other areas it faces an erosion of the international competitiveness of Australian industry. Most importantly, it faces a Prime Minister who no longer has the authority and respect that people previously believed he enjoyed. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Child)Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

text: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is talking about real rates of interest, yet he had people committing suicide at a 20 per cent rate of interest. We had record interest rates in this country. There is one thing about these Liberals-they cannot be made to face any shame; there is no shame in the Liberal Party. Where do we go? The Deputy Leader of the Opposition talks about our fudging on the exchange rates; that our actions on the exchange rate are being exposed. Who was the Treasurer who sat and let the Treasury over-value the exchange rate for years, while we had a wages explosion ripping our competitiveness apart on the way through? Why did we maintain the exchange rate system for those years? It is because the former Treasurer could not get a piece of tissue paper through Cabinet-he had neither the ability nor the guts to knock his Prime Minister over and get the Austr-lian dollar floated, to find its equilibrium in the market place. He kept the Australian dollar overvalued, ripping the guts out of our manufacturing industries, destroying the prospects of our export industries to compete, our primary export sector. While all of that was happening, we had a massive wages explosion, presided over by himself and  who was then the Minister for Industrial ReI lations. He says we are fudging it up on economic policy; we are fudging it up on the exchange rate. He says we have the wrong wage determination system. We have a wage determination system which has given us two years of back-to-back wage restraint and no increase in award wages for 12 months. He has the hide to say that that so called policy of his, which had wages blowing. out through nearly a decade, was the right policy. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition makes the point, with crocodile tears, of how much infllition will drift through the wage system as a result of changes in the exchange rate. He says that as though the conditions which currently apply in the economy would have applied under his policies. We would have already had the wage increases under his policies, right through 1984. We would not have had to wait for some move in the exchange rate to drift through wage indexation; we would have already seen our competitiveness eroded by the impact on wages of such a change, because they have no policy to deal with that. His policy is to let the powerful unions negotiate and to give centralised wage fixing to everybody else. In other words, he is saying that we should let the high points of the economy fight it out and then those massive increases will ratchet their way through the economy, as they have in the past, and in the end flow right through, as happened with the metal trades award of 1981. Eighteen months after that award even the bookmakers' clerks on the racecourses received an increase. It went through every sector of the economy. That is the wage system he implores us to have. Instead of that, we have an accord with the trade unions, based on fair and decent wage restraint as a trade-off for growth. In other words, the unions will restrain themselves for growth and for employment. They have done that, demonstrably;otherwise we would not have an inflation rate of only 5 per cent. Yet the Deputy Leader of the Opposition says it is the wrong wages policy. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) happens to recognise tht; fact that if changes in the exchange rate over time were to impact on the wage system there would have to be some trade off. However the accord permits negotiations in regard to these factors anyway and one cannot simply assume that any change in the exchange rate would automatically drift into wages. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition then had the hide to say that the Prime Minister is negating his responsibilities to this Parliament. The fact is that this Government has brought inflation down and it is the policies of this Government, not the policies of the coalition, which will lead this country through prosperity in the 1980s. So much for the wage fixation system. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition talks about the current account deficit. This Government is two years old. Does he think the structural problems of the economy and the current account deficit can all be laid at our door? What about the wage explosion of 1981 and Australia's loss of competitiveness? What has that done to the current account deficit? What about the impact of the massive pick-up in imports which has come as a result of this recovery? Of course that has an impact on the current account deficit, but for the right reasons. There is a lagged effect of a change in competitiveness. But, of course, everything comes in its time and with the right market mechanisms those corrections will take place. The Opposition has shed crocodile tears and wrung its hands about whether this Government can manage the economy. Nothing the former Treasurer has said throws any light upon any shift in policy on his part. He talked about the 1984 Budget as though there was something wrong with it. I have told him over and over again-he will not listen-that the smallest deficit is not necessarily the right deficit. We do not accept his view about dragging activity out of the economy too quickly. We will not cop that. The difference between his policies and ours is that the Government has its policy settings cast for growth. It is not just a government with a growth rhetoric; it has its fiscal and monetary policy settings cast for growth, backed up by a prices and incomes accord. We are not, as is the Opposition, advocating a contractionary fiscal policy and a monetary policy which will lead to a credit squeeze. The former Treasurer is advocating that we chase the 8 to 10 per cent target at a time of enormous upheaval in the relationship between the monetary aggregates and the gross domestic product as a result of this Government's historic deregulation of the financial system. He would have us mindlessly, foolishly and irresponsibly chasing a fictitious and cosmetic number, leading to a credit squeeze in this country and stalling growth, all because he is an unreconstructed monetarist. He always copped the view of the former Secretary to the Treasury and others who dominated his economic thinking during the 1980s. He will not accept that there is a basic difference in our philosophies. This is a government with a policy cast for growth; it is not a policy cast for the ideological obsessions of people in the Liberal Party or the business community. The results are there for everyone to see. Look at the Opposition's performance in the election campaign. It said that it believes in smaller .Budget deficits, but we found over $1,500m of new policy. There was the $500m of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the $500m of the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair), and then there were all sorts of other announcements around the place. Opposition members could not keep a fiscal policy together if they tried, yet they are trying us that there is something wrong with our Budgets. Last year we could have brought in a Budget deficit of about $5t billion if we had not· provided a tax cut. But the tax cut has given us wage restraint, amongst other things, as well as the pay back of some fiscal drag. The result is that we have a 5 per cent inflation rate for the first time since 1972. So where do Opposition members get off in telling us that our policies are wrong? They should not kid themselves about what members of the business community think; they should just go and talk to them. They should just pick up the newspapers and look at the restoration of profits across companies. Do honourable members opposite really think anyone in Australian business seriously believes that the Liberal Party of Australia has any policies to give noninflationary growth to this country? No one in business does. The business community has given members of the Liberal Party up. It has sold them out because they are not worth supporting. They have no ideas. They are bums when it comes to economic policies. The business community knows that they are bums and it will not wear them. I make that point very clear. text: We get it back. We have to read everything. We see it all. The fact of the matter is that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the great monetarist, the man who believes in monetary targets, never hit a monetary target once in five years as Treasurer. When the Budget came down in 1984-85 we said that we would look .to to tell adjustments for growth and if there was more growth mid-year than we thought, we would adjust the target up for growth and we wOllld adjust it for re-intermediation. Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Title: PETITIONS
text: The matter of public importance submitted by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is in the following terms: The growing doubts about the Government's ability and resolve to effectively manage the economy as exemplified by the recent depreciation of the Australian dollar. At stake here is the credibility of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Government with local and overseas financial markets and economic observers as to whether they can deliver on the various commitments they have made in economic policy. The Treasurer, who has been very good indeed at going around the board rooms and bourses of the world in a dark suit and talking about the collection of antiques, has presented a view of the Australian Labor Party to people here and abroad which is quite different from that presented during the previous period of Labor ter government. As we know, overseas ,investors had an opinion of a Labor government as !Jne that s-nt people around with letters from Jim Cairns, or sent Khemlani over to borrow $4,OOOm. They thought members of the Government had Iraqi breakfasts. This was the general image of the Labor Party within the international, business financial community. The Treasllrer had an exaspect tremely difficult task in removing this image backed up by the Prime Minister (Mr Haw-e), he went round all the board rooms and international conference tables to give a totally different pression of a Labor government. Basically what the Treasurer and the Prime Minister were saying was: 'We are not like Whitlam, Cairns, Khemlani or any of these people. We are sound economic managers. We have got the lunatics in our under total control. All the left wing fourth ANZUS?'. graders are people that we can put our finger on. We have got the trade unions, which caused immense damage under the previous Whitlam Government and also during 1981-82 under the Fraser Government, under control because we have got them constrained by the prices and incomes accord, a solemn agreement which they have signed. We are also supporters of the financial deregulation begun by the previous Treasurer following the Campbell report. We have also got Labor governments in the various States, which are perfectly sensible, run by common sense business type gentlemen who also wear dark suits and ties on public occasions. We are quite different from the previous Labor Government. You can trust us'. That impression was successfully implanted here and abroad. I must say that if Australia has to endure a Labor government for any period that impression is very useful. Members of the Opposition supported those aspects of Labor policy, particularly in the area of financial deregulation, which were sound and in the interests of Australia. We are talking about what has happened to the dollar over the last two or three weeks and what has happened in international financial circles; we are not talking about the general decline of the dollar which would happen for good economic reasons, but we are talking about the very substantial and dangerous wobbles that have occurred in addition to that. I suggest that they are occurring and may well continue to occur because the Government has shown that it is no longer able to control those critical elements of its constituency which enable it to maintain this international and local image. The first piece of evidence we have on this matis the MX virus that infected the Left and then got through to the Centre Left. Members of the Centre Left made an attack on their Prime Minister. Under pressure abroad, in the course of an overseas trip without full consultation with his colleagues, leaving the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) speechless in Sydney, the and Prime Minister changed his mind on a critical of our relationship with the United States and, of America under the ANZUS alliance. Inter. national observers could rightly ask: 'Is it possible also that the Treasurer will suffer a similar fate to imthat suffered by the Foreign Minister? Is it possible that the Prime Minister, under some similar kind of pressure from the Left, joined possibly by the Centre Left in a particular situation, will back , down on a domestic commitment which is just as Party important as that external commitment to I refer to the economic trilogy which is the centrepiece of this Government's forward economic plan. We support it insofar as it goes. We applauded it at the time. I must say that we expressed some doubt as to whether the Prime Minister had received full backing from his Cabinet on the matter. In fact, he had not. Nonetheless, he committed himself and that commitment to this trilogy has been noted by local and international communities. I remind the House that the trilogy is not to increase taxes at a faster rate than the growth in the economy, to reduce Government spending as a proportion of the nation's output and not to increase the Budget deficit as a proportion of the national product. Today in the House the Treasurer has tightened up that third element of that commitment by saying that the deficit will not increase in money terms. That was an important additional tightening of the commitment by the Treasurer in public today.

Speaker: Mr CARLTON

text: It is, as my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said, contradictory to the Governor General's Speech. Nonetheless, the Treasurer made this public statement here today. We note that. The Business Council of Australia, which had the same interpretation as the Treasurer, will be pleased to hear of that commitment. To this trilogy I add the not insubstantial additional commitment of not increasing the Medicare levy. That is the trilogy and that is a good set of commitments. It is as portant to Australia's future as the commitment to maintain the ANZUS alliance is important to our external defence. If we can be seen to go back on a commitment under ANZUS at the first whiff of grapeshot, what price the trilogy? That is the first problem caused by the MX virus. The second element cited by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister under which they could say that they were different from the Whitlam Government is that the trade unions were contained by the accord. The accord states that regardless of our international trading competitiveness, regardless of the capacity of individual firms or industries pay, wages overall will rise automatically with creases in prices. All the overseas experts know that that is not sensible in a competitive trading world, but they thought that that was the best that a Labor Government could do under the circumstances and they accepted that as· evidence of good intentions. But what do we find on the accord? At about· the same time as we have a backdown on the MX issue, we also have a Public Service strike which has immediate effects on the capacity to keep the promises of the trilogy because it immediately pushes up interest costs in the Budget, affects our external account and the flow of dollars in and out of Australia, causes further ructions in the value of the dollar but, most importantly of all, it tests the Goverriment's resolve in· maintaining the accord. I make particular reference to the circumstances concerning unemployment which resulted from the former Government's economic management during the last 12 months of its economic stewardship. Mr Bilney-A misnomer. Mr ROBERT BROWNYes, undoubtedly it is a misnomer. During the last 12 months of the Fraser Government unemployment in Australia' increased by a quarter of a million people. I hope the significance of that is not lost to all honourable members. What that means is that as a result of the economic policies which the Fraser Government initiated,' which it put into place, which it implemented, on every day of the last 12 months of that Government another 750 Australians' were thrown on to the unemployed scrap-heap. Speaker: Mr MARTIN
Title: PETITIONS
text: lnitially, that Madam Deputy Speaker, I congratulate you on your election as Chairman of Committees. I certainly look forward to serving under your astute for guidance during the life of this Parliament. I would like' you to convey my similar congratulations to Mr Speaker. I speak for the first time in this House with a very acute sense of honour and responsibility which the electors of Macarthur have entrusted to It is somewhat remarkable that, during the of this Parliament, no fewer than three former members for Macarthur, plus me, will share this terms building. The honourable member for Werriwa that (Mr Kerin) ably represented the people of the Macarthur between 1972 and 1975. His performwithin the Ministry has brought high critical to acclaim from his former constituents and the Australian people at large. Having failed last year to gain his own Party's preselection for a seat in the exchange New South Wales Parliament, Mr Michael to the Baume will join the Opposition ranks in the more Senate in July, My immediate predecessor and good friend, Mr Hollis, takes his seat within this House as the honourable member for Throsby. I believe it is traditional in a maiden speech to extend thanks to many people-to family, friends, political colleagues and so on. I take this opportunity to acknowledge publicly the support I have received from my wife Carol, the rank and file members of the Australian Labor Party in the electorate of Macarthur who selected me to contest the seat for Australia's only true party of social conscience, and, particularly, my very, close friend and mentor, the Hon. Laurie Kelly, Speaker of the Legislative Assembly in New South Wales. I also extend sincere appreciation to a former great Australian Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, who, although I only met him, formally, on the opening day of the Parliament, shook from me the shackles of political apathy and steeled my commitment to reform, social justice and equality for all Australians. Finally, and perhaps most importantly, I extend my thanks to the working class people of Macarthur who put me here. The electorate of Macarthur has emerged from the redistribution as a New South Wales south coast provincial and semi-rural electorate, stretching inland from the ,:!orthern Wollongong suburbs between Austinmer and Mount Ousley to include the ,towns of Wilton, Appin, Bargo, Picton, Tahmoor, Camden and Warragamba. As a life-long resident of Wollongong, I call fairly claim to be a son of Illawarra, completely familiar with its people, its problems and its aspirations. As a former high school teacher and university lecturer in Wollongong, it town planner in Campbelltown and an alderman of the WOllongong City Council, I bring to this House an intimate knowledge of the electorate and a desire and commitment to work for its advancement. I realise that this is no mean task. The once proud Illawarra-Macarthur region, famous world-wide as the cradle of Australia's rural industry, has been ravaged in recent years by twin evils-the effects of a major economic recession and board room decisions of overseas multinational companies and monopolies. Macarthur's recent economic history has been dependent almost totally on the well-being of manufacturing industry and the underground coal mining industry. With the decline of these, the very social and economic fabric of my electorate has undergone considerable change. Dominant in the manufacturing sector is the steel industry at Port Kembla which, although located in the neighbouring electorate of Cunningham, over many years, has provided employment opportunities for the residents of the Macarthur electorate. In 1981 Australian Iron and Steel Pty Ltd employed almost 20 per cent of the total employee population of the Illawarra region, while a considerable proportion of the remaining employment was found in enterprises directly related to or under the corporate umbrella of the steel industry. The lack of diversity in the regional economy earned W ollongong the title of 'steel city' and meant that the region was particularly vulnerable to the rapid structural change and the recession of the early 1980s. In the period of post-war industrial expansion the steel il1 dustry contributed to large scale employment generation and population growth, with an extremely high proportion of the work force being derived from overseas countries. However, by 1971 the progressive substitution of capital for labour and consequent produCtivity gains had led to a stabilisation of employment of around 20,000. At this time, through a combination of corporate' policy decisions and a belated recognition of the need to rationalise, in my view due largely to poor forward planning and a failure by the company to detect the warning signs that modern overseas steel plants would shortly create massive problems of competition for Australia, unemployment rates in the industry rose dramatically. Employment at the Port Kembla plant fell from 20,368 in 1981 to a current level of around 13,000. In addition, this crisis was amplified by the effect on subsidiary and dependent companies in the Illawarra-Macarthur regions. It is estimated that for each job lost in the steel industry another was lost in thy region. While it is not possible to determine precisely the current unemployment rate for the Macarthur electorate, a figure close to 20 per cent, based on data from the Commonwealth Employment Service and the Department of Social Security, is not unrealistic. However, to its great credit, this Government has responded positively to the crisis in the steel industry-a crisis reflected by international overproduction and the declining domestic demand for steel. In 1983 the steel industry's plan was announced which saw the industry, unions imd government agree to a wide range of options to encourage intensive modernisation and rationalisation at the Port Kembla plant and in other steel plants of Australia. Through union agreements on productivity, government agreements on steel import levels, guarantees of percentage shares in the Australian domestic steel market and industry guarantees regarding levels of investment in modernisation and expansion programs, a degree of stability has again been brought back into the industry. But a word of caution is necessary. Constant surveillance must be kept of changes in domestic and international economic conditions, particularly as reflected by levels of imports. The fact that these import levels have now reached 30 per cent of the local steel market is of major concern to the whole Illawarra community. I am pleased that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) is aware of this problem and has indicated that remedial action may be forthcoming. Further, the existing situation with respect to the levels of protection for the steel industries in other countries, particularly the United States of America and New Zealand, must be carefully monitored. The United States has recently limited its imports to 18.5 per cent of its steel needs and has been directly responsible for the excess of steel on the world market. Problems of negotiating steel agreements with New Zealand, despite the existence of the closer economic relations agreement between Australia and New Zealand, have had similar effects on steel production in Australia. I was pleased to read recently that the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) has made tentative plans to stage a mini-summit with representatives of the New Zealand Government to discuss this issue. Whilst I applaud this. initiative, I believe care must be taken to ensure that imports of New Zealand steel into Australia do not impinge upon the viability of the Australian steel industry. The problems of the manufacturing sector alone have not been responsible for the economic ills of the Macarthur electorate. It is fair to say that in recent years' no sector of my electorate has been more devastated than the coal industry. There are no fewer than 17 underground mines within the boundaries of Macarthur and neady 90 per cent of the electorate is underlain with black gold. Mining giants such as BP Australia Ltd, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd are all operative in the area, providing principally coking coal and some steaming coal for domestic and export markets. Since 1982 there have been massive retrenchments in the coal industry and a number of pits have been closed or rationalised. Unfortunately for my electorate, most retrenchments in New South Wales have taken place in the southern coalfields. Over 2,000 jobs have been lost in this area alone. The effect of those sackings on the mines and the community of the Illawarra and the Burragorang Valley and such towns as Camden, Picton and Tahmoor, has been nothing short of horrendous. Indeed, had it not been for the combined efforts of this Government, the Labor Government of New South Wales and the mining unions, many hundreds more miners would have been subjected to the same fate and other collieries would have been closed in the name of economic rationalisation. Yet within the industry it is now believed that underground mining has a brighter future in the long term, particularly in respect of open cut operations in New South Wales and Queensland. As well, latest production figures would seem to indicate that underground mining produces coal more cheaply. If this is the case, why is the industry of the south coast and the Burragorang Valley plagued by shutdowns and retrenchments? Optimism expressed within the industry must be tempered with a realisation that, both for the present and for the foreseeable future, companies must compete against each other for prized international markets in an economic climate of massive oversupply. With more than 20 million tonnes of hard coking coal stockpiled around the world, international coal contracts are being awarded only to the most efficient producers, or to those companies prepared to undercut prices offered by competitors. A major technical problem threatening the coal industry in the Macarthur area concerns the question of transportation. The construction of stage I of the Port Kembla coal loader has provided export facilities for hard coking coal, transported to the loader by rail and road. New South Wales State Government policy dictates that in most cases rail transport of coal must be used. The Maldon-Dombarton rail line under construction promises to alleviate some of the domestic transportation problems by allowing acceSs to rail by several of the southern district mines. However, freight charges associated with this form of transport, indeed, with all coal transportation, have contributed to the Australian coal industry's difficulties in competing with overseas suppliers such as South Africa. With the downturn in the demand for steel on the world market, the Macarthur region has started to exploit its steaming coal reserves in order to keep up production. Markets which have included India, Bangladesh and Pakistan have emerged, but because these countries have relatively small ports the coal must be shipped in smaller lots. Consequently, the price of the coal is proportionately higher. The whole structure of Australia's coal transportation system, including the question of freight rates, requires investigation, and an overall strategy needs to be devised. It is hoped that this may be the subject of review during this Parliament. What then is the future for the coal industry in both the Macarthur electorate and Australia generally? In the very long term the future is bright because the south coast underground reserves will far outlast ope'n cut seams. In the short term the Australian Coal Association believes that south coast collieries must turn to steaming coal for their sales. However, the problem onCe again is that steaming coal pays a lower price for the same production costs. Hence, the Association has called for south coast mines to restructure to remain competitive. Once again, this returns the industry to the bleak prospect of mine closures and large scale retrenchments in the name of rationalisation. Not all in the industry would agree with the assertion that the future is bright. It isimpossible to predict fluctuations in world demand for .coal, in prices obtainable in a climate of fluctuations in currencies, and in the desires of coal companies to expand or contract in response' to these and other factors. In the last 10 years, all the export collieries in the southern coalfields have come under the control of multinational oil and mineral corporations. Although these companies have increased their level of investment in technological advances, the southern coalfields remain vulnerable to fluctuations in the international market and to the investment programs of companies'withinterests in minerals, oil and gas, in not only other parts of Australia, but also other parts of the world. I was, pleased to read of the success that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) was able to achieve with theBritish Petroleum company during his recent trip to Europe. The agreement reached in respect of Burragorang Valley mines has meant that jobs have been saved and mine closures averted for a per-od at least. Yet this serves as a typical example of hqw the problems of coal marketing and the progress of the Australian coal industry are dealt with on a piecemeal basis. No overall, coordinated strategy has been devised to ensure security of employment, equal access to markets at agreed to prices and even the basic allocation of new coal leaSeS. Certainly, the establishment of the Coal Consultative Council by this Government in 1983 demonstrated the Australian Labor Party's commitment to becoming an active participant in the coal industry and to providing a framework for Government, companies and the trade unions to address the pressing problems of the industry. However, the crisis in the last year or so has clearly demonstrated the need for continued Federal intervention in price and tonnage negotiations and in the overall control of the industry. Labor Party policy calls for the establishment.of a coal industry authority charged with responsibility for redressing these problems. , Something must be done and done now, otherwise miners in the Macarthur electorate and in other mining areas of Australia will face a bleak future, a future which could see the continued economic and social decline of whole communities dependent on the mining sector. I believe that these two matters on which I have touched are of universal concern across a broad spectrum of ages and classes. However, I now turn to an issue of equal, if not greater, significance to every Australian. I refer to the problem of youth unemployment, which remains one of the great social tragedies of our time. January figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics indicated that between 1973 and 1983 the unemployment rate among teenagers increased by 18 per cent, three times the increase in the adult rate. Although Australia's overall unemployment rate has dropped to 8.5 per cent, which gives testimony to the Government's economic policies, the unemployment rate for teenagers is still a massive 21 per cent. Sadly, within the Illawarra-Macarthur region this figure has been estimated at 44 per cent for the 15 to 19 years age group and 37.1 per cent for the under 25 category. Notwithstanding these figures, as stated by the Sydney Morning Herald, believe it or not, the Hawke Government can rightly claim to be the first Government to tackle the issue of youth unemployment comprehensively. Initiatives such as the Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs have presented the Government with options to consider and policy decisions to make. But, as that Committee rightly points out, it is not reasonable to expect that problems which have been accumulating over many years can be easily eliminated. It has to be realised by politicians, bureaucrats, the community and, certainly, Australia's youth that Australia's economy is inextricably linked to the economies of other countries and that changes in technology, industry rationalisation policies and educationalopportunities for the acquisition of various skills will all affect employment opportunities in some way. Participation by youth in the community through a variety of schemes has been a notable achievement of this Government. Empty rhetoric from opponents of the Government's policies has been unable to detract from the fact that schemes such as the community youth Support scheme, the participation and equity progra-, the labour adjustment retraining arrangement and other youth training programs have achieved great success. It is a sad fact of life that, because of the trend to increasing casualisation of the work force, full time work has been difficult to get. School students effectively are depriving school leavers of either permanent part time or full time work. This increased casualisation is not because of high wages for school leavers, but rather a reflection of the extremely low wages paid to 15year-old casual workers. Studies such as those by Justice Macken in New South Wales have shown that nearly two-thirds of part time positions are held by school students. Macken's suggestion of the freeing of the penalty rates system and an increase in junior wages may help convert jobs currently held by casual workers into full time or manent part time work for school,leavers. It is fitting that 1985 has been designated national Youth Year because, as has so often been stated, the future of Australia rests with today's youth. This year provides a unique opportunity for governments, the community and the youth of Australia to work together in an atmosphere of consensus and commitment in an endeavour to come to grips with the complex nature of. the problems, desires and ambitions of today's youth. It is equally fitting that the three themes of the International Year of Youth-participation, development and peace-parallel the Australian Labor Party's own policy on youth. Issues of education, drug abuse and nuclear disarmament deserve to be discussed at length by and for today's youth so that all Australians will create for themselves a fair and just society of which they can be proud. I believe that, as a parent, I have every right to insist that my children grow up in a society which is going to reflect the norms and aspirations of this Government. 1 believe that it is this Government alone which can provide that atmosphere for my children to grow up in. I have touched on but three of the many issues of concern to my electorate and of great personal concern to me. I believe that this Government has the necessary credentials, commitment and competence to achieve great things, things that will benefit not only my electorate but also certainly Australia. My electorate certainly looks to this Government for its continued work and assistance. I am sure that my electorate will continue to support me as its member whilst ever this Government is delivering, and I am sure that this Government will continue to deliver. I thank honourable members for paying me the courtesy of listening tome.

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: PETITIONS
text: To represent the electorate of Farrer, stretching as it does from Mount Kosciusko, through Albury and Deniliquin to the South Australian border, is, indeed, a privilege. I thank my family and friends and my electors in Farrer who extended such strong support fo- me on 1 December 1984. I also thank my National Party supporters, both in the electorate and elsewhere, including my Federal Leader, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and my Deputy Leader, per- the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt). Farrer is a diverse electorate named after the Interfamous wheat breeder, William Farrer. The electorate was originally created in 1949 and has undergone several changes to its boundaries. Under the 1984 redistribution it has perhaps become the most elongated, non-metropolitan electorate in Australia. It commences a short distance inland from the New South Wales south coast at Mount Kosciusko and then utilises the Murray River as its southern boundary for hundreds of kilometres and ends at the South Australian border, not a great distance from the suburbs of Adelaide. In the east there is some magnificent mountainous terrain with the tourist gateway points of· Tumbarumba and Khancoban.' As one moves west the mountains give way to the foothills and plains with countless thousands of hectares of rolling farmlands and rural service towns along with irrigation farms and, in the far west, grazing tracts. The national growth centre, Albury, is the largest city in the Farrer electorate and is its effective capital. Many State and Federal departments have large regional headquarters at Albury: I might add that these are staffed in the main by efficient and effective public servants who properly provide considerable liaison assistance along with .the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation. Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd, Borg-Warner (Australia) Ltd and Macquarie Worsteds Ltd head the list of firms associated with the expanding industrial base. Along witp. this, equally important employment is generated through tourism in all its facets, including an expanded convention role for Albury. Outside Albury there is a series of large and small country towns battling for survival as the rural service town role contracts. The one exception is a bevy of towns along the Murray River in what I term 'the border club belt'. They are booming, particularly since the Victorian Government reaffirmed . its opposition to poker machines. There are record levels of investment in clubs and motels from Albury to Wentworth. The electorate of Farrer has had only two other representatives since it was created in 1949. I pay sincere tribute to a former Minister of the Crown and Ambassador to Holland, Sir David Fairbairn, and also to my immediate predecessor, a former Minister of the Crown, the present honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife). I also pay tribute to my National Party colleague who effectively represented the western quarter of Farrer, the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks), and to the former member for Hume, Stephen Lusher, for his decade of service. I take this opportunity to congratulate the Speaker on his election and also Madam Deputy Speaker on her election. I am delighted that the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Drummond) is the Deputy Speaker on this occasion, as we .share a common town of interest. We were both brought up in the Boree Creek-Lockhart area. In many ways Australia is at the crossroads, both on the international and domestic fronts. However, this situation is not reflected in the Governor General's address. While the international front will be dealt with by many other speakers in the course of this debate, I say only that the vast majority of Australians deeply resent the U-turn in the Australian-United States of America relationship arising from a telephone call from Senator Richardson, ensconced in Japan, to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), then ensconced in Europe. Those of us who were randomly selected by this Parliament to be involved in the ugly conflict of Vietnam at times thought that, if nothing else, as one of the few Western nations fighting alongside the United States of America, we were contributing to the special nature of the relationship between Australia and America. It will take years and a change of government here to rectify the damage to our Australian-American relationship over the last month. It could be a very lonely future for Australia without a special relationship with the United States, as. we need the United States, nuclear warts and all, more than it needs us. I wish to raise four particular areas on the domestic front. Firstly, I mention the 'Murray Valley where salinity has reached a crisis situation and with it the health of many people, including the people of Adelaide. Secondly, I mention the farm sector of the economy, which is in a crucial situation, as are many of its commodities. Thirdly, I mention tourism, particularly inland tourism, which is at the crossroads. Fourthly, I mention transport in Australia which is also at a critical stage, with inefficiencies, be they in relation to air, rail or road, and with crippling fuel taxation. Before dealing in detail with these four areas let me be clear about my overall intent. My intent is not only to provide full time representation for all electors in Farrer but also to seek to better the well-being Of our nation through less government and less taxation and the encouragement of individual enterprise. I quote a former great master of this House, Robert Gordon Menzies, who said: The great race of man is that one in which each in.dividual develops his fullest individuality, in which ambition is encouraged, in which there are rewards for the courageous and the enterprising, in which there is no foolish doctrine of equality between the active and the idle. I might add that another former Prime Minister, John MCEwen, put it more bluntly. He was 'for free enterprise, against socialism': If Australia is to be in great shape in the bicentennial year of 1988, or more particularly, in the centennial year of 2001, when we celt<brate 100 years of nationhood, 100 years of our Constitution and 100 years of the existence of this Parliament, Australians must have room to breathe from the high levels of taxation and room to be enterprising initiators. The individual entrepreneur must be unfettered so that he can go forward and generate economic activity and employment. I do not rule out a safety net under the truly needy. I am the first to recognise the huge and growing numbers of have-nots, be they farmers from Balranald or Berrigan or the young unemployed of the Lavingtons and Liverpools. However, I reiterate the general philosophy that less government and less taxation will do more to provide overall advancement than opposing alternatives and options, particularly heavy-handed big government requiring even bigger taxation. I turn now to the first area I mentioned, namely, the Murray Valley and the related Murray-Darling system, which embraces, part of Queensland and large areas of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. I have to tell the House that the salinity situation there is critical. Report after report and meeting after meeting catalogues the deteriorating situation. The most recent repor-, entitled 'Salt of the Earth', by the Victorian Parliamentary Salinity Committee is a further step forward. Whilst a good deal of the salinity is naturally occurring, it is difficult to comprehend that annually around 1.1 million tonnes of salt pass in solution in the Murray River into South Australia from upstream. To this, South Australia adds another half million tonnes of salt, so that the salt load peaks in the Murray River at around 1.6 million tonnes annually. This level is 480 milligrams per litre salinity, expressed in terms of soluble salts. But on an overall basis it is a fact that a cost and price squeeze is destroying the viability of farming, notwithstanding vaiiant and successful attempts to lift farm' productivity. The farming sector productivity cow has been milked dry. Without cost reductions or, alternatively, price increases, farmers in their hundreds, if not thousands, will go.to the wall. Nobody wants subsidy for subsidy's sake as a solution, but farmers are entitled to a fair go, with better marketing, long-term low interest finance, a review of taxa tion on fuel and other key farm cost items and, in general, a sensitive approach by government at all levels to hold and bring about proper policies and priorities. The dairy industry is currently in a hiatus and deserves special mention. I acknowledge the need exists to gain co-operation from the various State governments and this requirement has delayed the action of the Federal Government thus far; but I also suspect there are other reasons for the delay. I am advised that a senior officer of the Federal Department of Primary Industry has said that some 5,000 dairy farmers across the nation will have to leave the industry. It would be very wrong for the turmoil in the dairy industry to be allowed to continue to help pave the way for this and I reiterate my support for the Australian Dairy Industry Conference amended national marketing plan, as this is the correct approach and any outbreak of interstate milk war will, in the long term, be devastating for all dairy farmers. I turn now to the question of tourism and the need to further boost tourism in Australia, with reference to the inland areas. To a large extent, there is a lack of realisation that there are'many family-oriented, low-cost tourist activities available across inland Australia. Whilst these activities relate to locations which do not enjoy the same degree of exotic attraction as coastal areas and overseas, they nevertheless help complement and balance the tourist resources available in this country. The activities and locations to which I refer range from climbing Mount Kosciusko, which I did recently to visit the easternmost point of my electorate and familiarise myself with the Kosciusko National Park, to canoeing down the Murray River or hiring houseboats near the confluence of the Darling and Murray Rivers at Wentworth. These high penalty rates, applicable across large sections of the tourist industry, bring about additional costs for tourists odewer services being available for tourists on public holidays and weekends. Even the Federal Minister for tourism at one stage indicated his concern about this issue, but the, problem still remains and is seriously hampering the tremendous boost for the tourist industry throughout Australia. Speaker: Mr WRIGHT
Title: PETITIONS
text: As is the traditiQn, Mr Deputy Speaker, I jQin Qther members in cQngratulating Mr Speaker and Madam Deputy Speaker Qn their re-electiQn to.' their high and honourable Qffices in this Parliament. The electorate of Capricornia, since its creation in 190 I, has been represented by parliamentarians who have served this House and their constituencies with dedication .and in some cases with distinction. I consider myself fortunate to have known three of the previous Labor members on a close personal basis. The Hon. Frank Forde, who, like myself, was also a State member for Rockhampton, held many and varied positions in this Parliament, including that of Prime Minister of Australia. During his 25 years in Federal politics, from 1922 to 1946, he never wavered from his commitment to people or to his country, and that commitment remained with h-m until his recent passing. George Henry Gray entered Federal politics in 1961 when he recaptured Capricornia for the Australian Labor Par- after it had been almost 16 years in non-Labor hands. His untimely death in 1967 was a great personal loss to me, for it was through his encouragement and support that I joined the ALP and embarked on a cateer in politics. It is, however, to George Gray's successor and my predecessor that I wish to pay a particular and special tribute. The Hon. Dr Douglas Nixon Everingham, Federal member for Capricornia from 1967 to 1975 and from 1977 to 1984, and Minister for Health in the Whitlam Labor Government, should never be forgotten by this House. He deserves special recognition for his contribution to humanity, not just as a parliamentarian, as a Minister and as a doctor, but moreover as a human being whose care and concern for others was always placed above his own ambitions, his own popularity and sometimes his own political preservation. .Doug Everingham's electoral support transcended party-political boundaries, and I am indeed conscious of the personal challenge before me as I endeavour to emulate his 16 years of service to his electorate, to the Australian community and to mankind generally. I take this opportunity to place on record the thanks and appreciation of the people of central Queensland for a job well done and to wish both Doug and his wife Beverly a most satisfying retirement. It was my intention to use this, my maiden speech, to canvass a number of issues which are of personal concern to me, including the, problems, confronting Australian seamen on the Australian National Line, the alarming drug problem in our nation and other matters affecting the State of Queensland, caused mainly by the incompetence· and misguided policies of the National Party State Government. However, as there is a 20 minute limit on speeches, I intend to raise these issues greater length at another time during the session. As a former State parliamentarian, it is appropriate for me to make an observation about our system of federalism. During my 15t years in the Queensland Legislative Assembly, I saw this system in operation at close quarters-sometimes, I might add, being left aghast and amazed at how the principle of federalism could' be misinterpreted, manipulated and blatantly twisted to suit the political advantage of the Bjelke-Petersen Government. But, setting that aside, I readily acknowledge the importance of the States within the Federal structure and I am cognisant of the role played by State governments and; in turn, local authorities in ensuring that the decision making process operates on a more decentralised, people-oriented basis. However, I also recognise that more and more in today's society, there are matters which, in the interests of Australians as a whole, are better dealt with at the national level, irrespective of the fact that traditionally the relevant area of administration might come within the pu'rview of the States. I direct my remarks specifically to the issue of consumer product safety as it relates particularly to the recall of unsafe goods. This issue is of fundamental importance to every Australian consumer-to every man, woman and child in the nation. Product safety is a matter of life, death and possible lasting injury. Yet, despite its broad and vital significance for the community, there has been limited action taken in the. legislative chambers of this land to alleviate and redress the numerous problems that have arisen in the Australian market-place because of the retailing of defective and dangerous products. I doubt that any member of this House would deny the right of consumers to be .able to buy goods which are safe and which do not pose a threat to their lives or health. Every Australian has the right t9 expect that products put on the market are adequateiy safe under conditions of normal use and/or foreseeable misuse, and cert-inly people have the right to expect that they will not be unreasonably exposed to any hazard to their life or health. Product safety has been addressed in part by the Parliament and by those of the States, but there is little uniformity in administration and there is, in my view, a serious shortcoming in what the relevant laws seek to achieve.' I take the Trade Practices Act as an example. The objective of this legislation is to prevent unsafe goods from being sold on the Australian market. This is done by a series of product safety standards, many of which have been develat oped through the excellent work of the Standards Association of Australia. However, despite this legislation, despite the work of government agencies and despite supervision by the majority of manufacturers, defective and dangerous products are still reaching the shop shelves' and are being bought by unsuspecting Australian consumers. Legislatures, Federal, State andlerritorial, have the power to ban an unsafe product, but being able to ban is not enough. A product banned from sale under the Trade Practices Act is not necessarily recalled; nor is the public necessarily warned of the danger. The same applies under State and Territory laws and, as far as I am aware, no banned product in this nation has ever been recalled. Even though the power exists to ban the sale of unsafe goods, nowhere in Australia is there the power to recall those goods. The failure of this Parliament and of the States to develop an effective recall procedure for defective products has existed for too long and must not be allowed to continue. I welcome the attention and the excellent coverage that has been given' to this issue by the Age newspaper and encourage that newspaper in its endeavours to develop a public awareness of this problem. I welcome also the recent undertaking by the Federal Attorney-General, the Hon. Lionel Bowen, in his capacity as Minister responsible for consumer affairs, to raise the concept of a national consumer product safety commission at the May meeting of the nation's Ministers for Consumer Affairs. The problem of recalling unsafe goods is, however, not a new one. In 1978 Senator Gietzelt spoke on this issue in another place and since then there has been much discussion and deliberation by Ministers at the various levels of government, but regrettably there has been little positive or effective legislative, action. In the Press release of 16 September 1983 the Standing Committee of Ministers for Consumer Affairs 'expressed strong concern that although the Commonwealth, most States and territories, had legislation giving power to ban unsafe products, there was presently no legal power to compel the recall of banned products'. That was 18 months ago. Those Ministers clearly realised the shortcomings of the law but nothing has been done to rectify the situation. In the United States there has been national mandatory redl.lliegislation since 1972, and some of the States took action even as far back as 1906. In the United States, manufacturers know that if their product is found to be hazardous, a certain procedure must be followed to ensure that the product comes off the market and that the public is immediately warned of the danger. In Australia, there is no such requirement. In this country there is even great difficulty in getting agreement as to what is a safety related defect. One government authority may act against a product but there is no guarantee that others will follow suit. A State by State comparison chart was published last week by the Age of more than 50 products which had been banned by a government somewhere in Australia. Not one of the products listed has been banned across the nation despite the danger to life or health and the risk of injury and many have been banned by only a minority of authorities. For example, the Magic Water Snake, containing water contaminated with human sewage, was. banned only in Queensland. The Grazyfoam, an inflammable aerosol bath foam for children, was banned only in New South Wales. The Espree Magwheel Cleaner, which contains a hazardous concentration of hydrofluoric acid, was banned only in South Australia. Swimming pool skimmer boxes shaped like a child's potty, but which could disembowel children if sat upon, were banned only in New South Wales. The World's Cutest Doll, the head' of which is easily detached, revealing a long metal spike, was banned only in Western Australia. The Gen Bag, a portable container used for the emergency transport of fuel, but found to be unsafe for that purpose, was banned only in Victoria. Sesame Street Jewellery, containing a high lead content, was banned only in Western Australia. Tasmania is the only State to have banned a baby rattle which incorporates a series of steel prongs. The Trade Practices Commission is the only body to have banned an electric shock attache case which gives more than the thief a volt. Only the Northern Territory and Tasrnania have acted against a brand of wire disc paint stripper which can break up, causing injury to the user. There are 30 other products which have been found to be dangerous but which have been banned by three or fewer of the State, Commonwealth and Territory authorities. Regrettably, products declared unsafe in one State can quite legally remain on the market in another State. A recent example of this was 'the Magic Egg'. This product was promoted as a 'wonder growing pet', and consisted of small plastic toys which expanded up to 10 times their size when immersed in water. I need to say little more about the danger the toys posed to children when swallowed. It was banned first in the Australian Capital Territory and later by the Trade Practices Commission, then in Victoria, New South Wales, South Australia, and Western Australia; but it is still able to be sold in Queensland, Tasmania and the Northern Territory. It is not unknown for manufacturers faced with a ban on their product in one State to dump it in another until the system catches up with it. I believ- there is too much reliance on self-regulation by manufacturers, too much reliance on llelfimposed but basically unenforceable codes of conduct and too much reliance on the hope that the manufacturers' sense of responsibility will overcome commercial considerations. I appreciate that most manufacturers are responsible and that they take every step 'to warn the public of any possible danger. I know also of manufacturers who are not so responsible. I know of those who cannot recall their products even if they want to. A tragic example of this was the case of the salami-salmonella outbreak in 1981. Because the manufacturer did not have any way of identifying the defective product, or knowing to whom it was sold; it was not possible to mount a recall and great suffering followed with more than 200 people across Australia being hospitalised. The market-place must also contend with the rogue operators who an- not bound by any code of conduct except self-interest and who are a threat to consumers and also to responsible manufacturers. Equally, of course, there are some very large corporations which have allowed commercial considerations, or what I call their cash register consciences, to overcome their social responsibilities and which pay no more than lip service to recails. I support this claim with the June 1980 report on tyre safety by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety. Paragraph 157 of that report said: It is concluded that one Australian tyre manufacturer acted irresponsibly in not recalling'tyres produced in the initial stages of its steel-belted manufacturers knew were failing at an unacceptably high rate and were thus placing many people ,at risk. There have also been instances where there have been unacceptable delays between the discovery of the defect and the warning to the public. For example, a distributor of Ducati motorcycles took 2 months grudgingly to agree to replace the alloy wheels on those machines, d-pite the public revelation that the wheels were collapsing. In 1981, even after considerable pr:essure from the Australian Automobile Association, it took the Ford company seven months to notify the public of a fault in its Cortina models made between 1971 and 1974. The fault was a carburettor fitting which sometimes allowed the fuel line to loosen and spray fuel over the engine, resulting in an unusually high number of under-bonnet fires. Ford rejected the request for a recall of the 40,000 vehicles involved but finally placed notices in newspapers referring to a special field action that the company was undertakin- on these cars. This is just one instance where manufacturers have used any other word but the word 'recall'-an,instance where the public had no indication of the fact that the car might have some safety related defect. There are also the hidden recalls. In the case of the Volvo company in 1981, the cars were not recalled; instead the owners of a particular model were invited to bring their cars in for inspection. As well as the hidden recalls, there are also those which are tucked away in the classifieds section of the major dailies-the buried recalls, ilS I call them. One notorious example of this was in relation to a baby thermal feeding bowl-a bowl which, if a certain part was removed, could choke or scald the child. The advertisement placed by the manufacturer measured only four centimetres deep by one column, wide-about the size of a postage stamp. I do not believe in government regulation for its own sake. If self-regulation works, I prefer it that way. But self-regulation in this field of product safety has failed, and there are many responsible bodies and organisations that clearly concur with that opinion. The Standing Committee of Cone sumer Affairs Ministers said of voluntary recall codes: They appeared often to have been honoured more in the breach than in the observance. The National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council in its 1984 report said: There is a demonstrated need for some form of government regulation of product recall in Australia. The Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations said recently: radial production which the There is no way of monitoring if producers are adhering to their codes or not, and companies outside industry associations are not controlled even by voluntary codes. It went on to say: Voluntary recall codes are deficient and offer little or no protection to consumers, AFCO went on to say: A mandatory recall code must be introduced under which products must be recalled within a specified minimum time of being found dangerous. In 1981 the Victorian Consumer Affairs Council advocated recall legislation, and as long ago as 1974 the National Committee of Inquiry on Compensation and Rehabilitation in Australia recommended: There should be provision to order the manufacturer to recall, repair, replace, or provide a refund for a defective or dangerous product. It also recommended that such a law should be a Federal, not a State, law. The Committee of Inquirysaid: ,Safety is a national concern and the manufacture, sale and distribution of products is not and cannot be confined within state boundaries. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety recommended inter alia that the Governmentintroduce legisl-tion to require the recall of defective or unsafe products. That was in June 1980. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, of which Australia is a member, has also recommended that member nations legislate or act, firstly, to ensure that consumers are 'Yarned without delay of products which present a substantial and severe hazard and, secondly, to enable unsafe products to be recalled. When considering this matter, it is necessary for honourable members to understand that Australia has developed as a national market and that only one statute should deal with the recall of goods. Moreover, where safety is involved the ability to take urgent action is essential and this cannot always be achieved with seven different laws. There is growing and widespread recognition of the need for mandatory product recall procedures to deal with the situation where there is a safety related defect. Why then, I ask; is it so difficult to make progress in Australia? I suggest the reason stems from a reluctance on the part' of this Parliament, regardless of who has occupied the treasury bench, to act for fear of upsetting the States and Territories and of being accused of encroaching on their traditional legislative domain within our Federal structure. It is an understandable attitude, but it is no longer acceptable-certainly not to me. The issue of product safety and the recall of hazardous goods is, as I have demonstrated, a problem of national dimension. It is a problem that calls for a national response, not just a patchwork approach by interested State legislatures. It calls for positive national leadership by this Parliament. There is an urgency for this Parliament to act to guarantee that product safety exists in the market place by ensuring not only that dangerous goods are banned but also that a mandatory warning and recall procedure or code exists-a procedure which can be implemented quickly and which can be enforced Australia wide. It is my hope that this, the Thirty-fourth Australian Parliament, will mark a new era for consumerism in this country and that through its legislative efforts a swift end will be put to the prevailing practice of hazardous' products continuing to be sold in the market place despite the exposure, despite the condemnation, and despite the banning by responsible authorities.
