Title: PETITIONS
text: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. In common with several other speakers this afternoon, whilst this is my maiden speech in this place, and for the electorate of Moncrieff, I am now not new to the forms of parliament. However, I am delighted that you are in the chair for my maiden speech and I ask you to convey to the Speaker and to the Deputy Speaker - y congratulation- on their - lection to their posItions and my hope that I WIll serve in this place for a long time, perhaps in their company. I have had the opportunity to serve the people of Queensland in the Australian Senate for 10 years but I am particularly delighted that the people of Mon.crieff have given me this opportumty to serve In the house of government in the national Parliament. I take this opportunity, as is traditional in maiden speeches, to convey my thanks 'to'those people and to some others. My thanks go to Liberal Party supporters in Moncrieff, who showed incredible dedication to the cause of the Liberal Party winning the seat. I th-nk my Liberal Senate and House of Representatives colleagues who gave me guidance and persona.1 support throughout the campaign, and in partIcular the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron), a former member for the electorate of Fadden, and the honourable member for MCPherson (Mr White), both of whom, as Liberal members of the House of Representatives have represented those areas which now make up the new Feder;l electorate of Moncrieff. I thank my husband for his personal and practical support as he underwent the experience for the first time of the hurly-burly of an Australian election campaign. I pay special tribute and convey special thanks to my parliamentary leader, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), for the leadership he gave to the Liberal Party in the election campaign and to all its can-idates, myself included, particularly because of hIS personal support on two occasions in the electorate of Moncrieff. I believe that it was his unswerving faith in the principles and policies of the Liberal Party and his unflagging energy and enthusiasm for the task in hand that lead us to the success we had. He certainly made a major contribution to my success, for which.! shall always be grateful. Not only am I making my maiden speech as the member for Moncrieff but also I have the great privilege of being the first member for that new Federal electorate. I congratulate the Australian Electoral Commission for its decision to honour Gladys Moncrieff in this way. She was a great Australian and one of its most truly loved Born in Bundaberg in 1896, she, unlike the daughters of many parents in those days, was supported by her parents in her ambition to have a stage career. She was 'also supported by people of the community from which she departed-that is, Townsville-to make her name in Sydney. She was highly successful in vaudeville and with the encouragement of, amongst other people, another great Australian, Dame Nellie Melba, joined J. C. Williamson's where she had a very successful career in musical comedy. It was in 1921, at the age of 30, that she first played the role of Teresa in Maid of the Mountains and she was known forever afterwards to all Australians as 'Our Glad'. Shewas a smash hit in this role and in her lifetime gave more than 3,000 performances of it. While she was successful in many other roles, that is the one with which she has always been most closely identified. She had successful visits to Britain, New Zealand and South Africa but, while she received cri,tical acclaim in those countries, by her own choice &he chose to stay in Australia for her entire career rather than seek international fame. She did many things in her lifetime but she will be remembered for coming out of retirement to visit New Guinea to sing to Australian troops during World War II and for touring cities and country towns throughout Australia in support of the war effort. She came out of retirement once more to go to Korea when Australian troops were sent there and, in fact, she was the first Australian entertainer to visit Korea to lift the morale of Australian troops involved in those hostilities. her support of Australian troops in theatres of war she was awarded the OBE. She was famous for, amongst other things, her numerous retirements. She tried to retire. on many occasions but the Australian public just did not want to let her go because they treasured her sweet voice and personality. Finally, in 1963 at the age of 71 years, she tired to the Isle of Capri on the Gold Coast. Whilst she might have enjoyed a well earned retirement, she also enjoyed promoting the Gold Coast and tourism, its great industry. Canal boats that took tourists through the waterways of the Gold Coast used to detour through the canal on which her home was built and she would frequently appear to greet those on the boats. She is well loved and remembered on the Gold Coast for that and for her personal support of the tourism industry. She died in 1978 at the age of 84 years and she was mourned widely. Many feltthat her death was a loss to the Australian family. I will leave my final word on her to a quotation from citizens. the book 100 Famous Australian Lives: Someone once described Gladys Moncrieff's career as a long love affair between an actress and an entire nation. But perhaps that is incorrect in one detail. Nearly aIJ love affairs have ups and downs-the rough with the smooth. But for Gladys Moncrieff, once she had captured the hearts of a whole country, there were never any failings out of favour. The Australian general public loved 'our Glad' fiercely from the time she first came to their attention ... . The electorate of Moncrieff is very large-over 3,000 square kilometres-varied arid very fast growing. It has an annual increase in population of between 30 and 40 per cent per annum. It comprises parts of three local authorities-the Beaudesert and Albert shires and Gold Coast City. As I have mentioned, it was' previously part of the old electorates of MCPherson and Fadden. It is very rich in resourceS, both physical and human. Amongst its physical resources are fertile land and great natural beauty. That land supports the major rural industrieS of beef, dairying, sugar and sm-ll crops, and the area is a major centre in Australia for growing rhubarb and avocados. Its natural beauty is well known. It is famous for its beaches and waterways of the Gold Coast and the well mountains and national parks of Tamborine and the Queensland-New South Wales border. But to these great riches have come human resources and it is noteworthy that there is a very high concentration of small entrepreneurs throughout the electorate. The, small entrepreneurs have built the Gold Coast to what it is today-the premier tourist resort in the Australia. Tourism on the Gold Coast has been For built up by small business people and therefore those things that affect small business very much affect it. In recent years major hotel corporations have also established themselves imd are continuing to establish themselves on the Gold Coast but the region's source, its backbone and continuing prosperity will depend on the small person. Farmers also utilising the rich natural resources of rethe soil are small business people. They are important particularly in the Beaudesert area of the electorate. Unlike many country towns of Australia, Beaudesert is growing and prospering. I know from my time representing Queensland in the Senate that that is not a general story about country towns these days. Too many are stagnating or sliding back, wondering about their future, but the future of this area is assured. The third major centre of population is Beenleigh, which was previously a small country town. Sugar is still amajor industry there; nevertheless Beenleigh has been caught up in the urban sprawl of Brisbane and is rapidly becoming a satellite of that city. I might say that the major industry in Beenleigh is people and it has a great future. However, my electorate does have problems. Its principal problem is the Hawke Government. The last election saw a 2 per cent swing against Labor and also a substantial swing against the Australian Democrats. Before the Labor Party retreats in its thinking and chooses to put that fact into the pigeon-hole labelled 'informal' I would like to iriform the House that I personally examined the recounted 'informal vote in MoncriefI'. I can state as a fact that the electorate was confused by the change of voting system. A large number of those informal votes showed just the figure '1' against a candidates' name. I am sure that the people who voted that way believed that they had voted formally because voting in that manner constituted a formal vote for the Senate. However, that type of informal vote was split 50-50 between the Labor Party and the coa:lition parties. There was no particular disadvantage to the Labor Party in the informal vote in Moncrieff. The swing against it and the swing to the coalition parties were genuine indications of disillusionment on behalf of the electorate and a growing apprehension at the future of this country under the Hawke Government. That disillusionment stemmed from the contrast between promises and performance' of the Hawke Government. The growing apprehension ,stems from the effect of policies it had alre-dy enacted which reduce individual choice in this country and which people fear are leading to irrevocable changes in our way of life. An, outstanding feature of the population of Moncrieff is that it has a very high proportion of retirees and very young people. The extremes of age groups are very high in proportion to the total population. I will mention during my speech some matters that particularly impinge on those age groups but I want also to talk about some other matters that concern me as.l know they concern the people whom I represent. It is fortunate for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that he did not keep his 1983 election promise to serve his full term. I have no doubt at all that, in the light of the 'MX missile affair and the response to it that I have had within my electorate, had the Prime Minister delayed the election until May this year this Government would have been out on its ear. So shortly after its re-election it has shown its Achilles heel, its inability to deal resolutely with things which are of extreme national significance. There are ongoing issues and there will be issues in the future which will lead to a steady erosion of support for the Labor Party. I believe that at the next election this Government will be out and there will be a return of the Liberal-National Party coalition. As this Government continues in office and as more of its policies are implemented people will have a growing awareness-they had only the beginning of an awareness in the last election-of what a Labor Government means. As this Government steadily implements its truly socialist objectives while speaking softly and wearing velvet gloves, nevertheless the electorate knows what is happening because people are affected. A classic case, probably more pointed in Queensland thari in other States, nevertheless relevant in other States, has been the introduction of Medicare, the classic two-card trick. It costs more and you get less. It costs more because of the levy and the fact that those who still choose to insure themselves privately are paying far higher rates, together with losing tax deductibility for the rates that they pay. I am sure that it carne as a rude shock to people in February last year when they made the necessary readjustments to their health insurance to discover that there was to be no gap insurance. I, along with many other members of parliament, received many inquiries and complaints about the inability of people to have something that they had before. Previously, those who chose to insure themselves privately could choose the percentage of their insurance. Having lost medical insurance rights they now find that they will get only 85 per cent of the scheduled rebate fee. Many of them asked why. Why indeed! Why would it matter to a government whether people ' had insurance in this basic area of need-health care? It should not matter at all to the finances of the Government if people choose to do that. But that is a decision that was made in line with socialist objectives. This Government's objectives in relation to our health scheme are no secret: We do not want the British health scheme. We do riot want to see happening in Australia what has happened in Britain-a perfectly good and outstanding health scheme reduced in so many'areas. We have had a good health scheme for many years. If this Government truly consulted the people of Australia and stated what its ultimate objectives in the health area were I am sure that it would be roundly rejected on that base if on none other. Another area which affects the very high number of retirees that I have in my electorate-it does not affect just them; it affects all peoplehas been the Government's move in the areas of superannuation taxation and the assets test. The most profound thing that one can do to affect people's behaviour throughout their lives is to structure or influence their expectations about their retirement. People, throughout their lives, work and plan for that time of their lives when they will no longer work, either because they do not want to or because they cannot. They make economic and behavioural decisions throughout their lives in line with those expectations. I ask as I did in relation to Medicare: Why would the Government have initiated this move on taxation of lump sum superannuation? It is known that there is virtually no immediate benefit to the Government in terms of taxation revenue. It is estimated that it will take at least 10 years before the full effect of revenue from this flows into the Government's coffers and becomes significant. Why then would a government risk unpopularity by this sort of move?It is, because it has long t-rm objectives. Those objectives are in line with the action it has taken on the assets test. It intends to structure and limit Australians' options in retirement. It suits socialist governments for citizens not to be independent of them and not to have rights·of choice. It suits governments to have them dependent on bureaucracy and government directive because then government can limit options. The more limit there is and the more effective it is the cheaper it gets for government. Truly, those who have been affected by these two measures and those who will be affected have very good reason for apprehension at the introduction of a capital gains tax and estate duties. These are two more taxes of the same kind. They limit people's choices, they limit their rights, they limit their horizons and, ine-itably, they limit their behaviour throughout their lives. If people believe that it is better .to spend rather than invest because they will only be penalised-that is a comment that has been made to me by plenty of people as I have travelled around my electorate and around Australia-we will have a very different sort of Australia in 20 years time. I believe that nobody would have voted for this Government in 1983 or 1984 if he or she had truly' understood this . The plight of the young is a matter that is canvassed frequently and I am sure that it will be Cllnvassed in the future. Time will not permit me to say very much on this matter. The statement in the Governor General's Speech relating to education participation is one of the greatest frauds of all times. I am pleased that none of the Government speakers has chosen to refer to it. Whilst the Government announced that it was going to increase the number of people participating in tertiary education it did not give those tertiary institutions the resources they needed to provide that number of places. It is nonsense for the Government to say to universities, colleges and technical colleges that they must tak<;: so many more students but with only a marginal increase in funding, and then tp qlaim that one has done one's best to increase participation. It does not wash and the figures will show that. The alternative would be a lowering of standards. It will be interesting to see whether Professor Peter Karmel has any comment to make on that aspect of standards in education in Australia in the report he is due to give to the Government, according to the Governor General's Speech. For many young people the Community Employment Program has been a tragic let down. This Government has created a bucket and shovel brigade. It has set up CEP projects in my electorate using antiquated methods that I had not seen in my lifetime. Far from giving to young people some skills that they could offer to employers, because of the artificial requirements for labour intensity all we are giving them is temporary and tantalising employment. We are not giving them skills that ernployers truly need. Finally, I refer to the frauds that are being perpetrated in the primary industry area. The sugar and dairy industrieS are two very large industries in my electorate. They are two highly significant rural industries in Australia. I very much doubt that the sugar farmers will ever be sweet-talked by this Prime Minister again. He has' done it, twice and they have seen nothing for their conversations and conferences with him. It appears that the dairying industry problems now move towards resolution, no thanks at all to the Hawke Government. In view of the great public expectations that the Australian people had of the Hawke Government when they first elected it, it is sad that those expectations have been dashed. There were some fine words iIi the Governor General's Speech. I am sure the Prime Minister will continue to offer us fine words; both in this forum and in other places throughout Australia. However, this Government will be judged on its deeds, not on its words, and that will lead to its inevitable failure.

Title: PETITIONS
text: Mr Drummond)Before I call the honourable member fOf Dobell, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech. I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: PETITIONS
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I congratulate you on your election to the office of Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives. I hope that you will convey my congratulations to the .Speaker and Chairman of Committees. I am sure that you will all discharge your responsibilities with great distinction. On 1 December 1984, a clear majority of Australians cast their votes for the Australian Labor Party. A clear and sizable majority of Australians voted to endorse the Hawke Government's mandate for continued economic recovery and reconstruction. As the Australian Labor Party's candidate, I had the honour, on 1 December 1984, of being elected the first member for Dobell. As all honourable members would be aware, this new electorate has been named after Australia's greatest portrait painter, Sir William Dobell., In the words of his biographer, James Gleeson, this is what portraiture was to Dobell. Portraiture was a serious study in which he attempted with all the honesty, sensitivity and technical skill at his command to wrestle into paint the personality that lay within. William Dobell lived at Wangi for 30 years. While working at Eraring power station I had the pleasure of meeting many of Bill Dobell's neighbours and friends. They all recalled his humility and friendship. Following the December election, I attended my first meeting of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party in the Government party room in this building. After observing that two of Dobell's greatest portraits', the Billy Boy and the Cement Worker, dominate one wall of the party room, I can only conclude that the good jUdgment of the Labor Caucus extends to art as well as to government administra tion. Prior to the 1984 redistribution, the constituents of the electorate of Dobell were represented by three distinguished members of this House. The honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen), who now serves his country ,as Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, represented most of the electorate of Dobell during his 15 years in the ijHouse of Representatives. His reputation on the central coast as a hard workinglo-al member is well deserved. The honourable  believe, be remembered as Australia's mostenergetic and reformist Minister for Transport since the Second World War. Both the honourable member for Robertson and the honourable member for Shortland have represented me in this House as my Federal member. However, lowe a different debt to my friend the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). The honourable member gave me,' and many thousands of other students, a thorough grounding in economics and Australian economic history. If the many speeches in this chamber of the honourable member for Charlton continue to be u,nsuccessful in educating members of the Opposition, I am prepared to provide the Liberal Party of Australia with a copy R. J. Brown's, Student Economics. I am sure that, with study, their standard of debate will improve. I am happy to acknowledge the assistance and advice these three colleagues have given me in recent days. I come to this House at the comparatively young age of 27. I express to my family and friends on the central coast and in Cronulla my thanks for the help and assistance they have given to me over many years. I also thank the many hundreds of Labor Party members and supporters who worked so tirelessly during the' election campaign. Without their help I would not be standing here today. I know that the second Hawke Government will continue to work to fulfil their hopes and dreams for a better Australia. In 1972,13 years ago, Australia's Prime Minister was Sir William MCMahon. At that time the Liberal-Country Party coalition had been in power for 23 consecutive years. When our sportsmen and women were presented medals at the 1972 Munich Olympics, God Save the Queen was played as the Australian flag was raised. At that time, Australian troops were fighting in Vietnam. Young men were being conscripted for military service before they were eligible to vote. In 1972, Australia's foreign policy wa- subservient to that of the United States of America. The age pension paid to senior citizens was a miserly 20.3 per cent of average weekly earnings. In October 1972 I joined the Cronulla Branch of the Australian Labor Party, mainly because its Federai Leader was Gough Whitlam. In the policy speech Gough Whitlam delivered at the Blacktown Civic Centre in November 1972, he stated that one of his aims was 'to liberate the talents and uplift the horizons of the Australian people'. One of the greatest achievements of the Whitlam Government was to place urban and regional development on the nation's agenda; On 16 August 1970, Gough Whitlam outlined the Australian Labor Party's policy in this area in these words: Inequality in Aust-alia is more publ;,? than privilte. A family's standard of living is determined much more by where they live than by what they earn. The inequalities between regions are now far greater than any between States, and indeed greater than they ever were between States. In developing regions the inequalities and the burdens are growing. The areas with the greatest needs are precisely those 'with the least resources. The Commonwealth Grants Commission was set up to advise the Commonwealth on the fairest way to help the smaller States provide services equal to those of the larger States, The Commission should now be asked to recommend the amount of Commonwealth, assistance required to remove the inequalities in servicing our developing suburbs and regions. If today Federal funding to local government were reviewed on that basis the local councils within the electorate of Dobell would rank as some of the most deprived in this coilntry. This has been brought about by twb factors: firstly, the area is growing rapidly. Since 1976, Wyong shire, which covers most of my electorate, has had an annual population increase of 8 per cent. Development in new areas has not been accompanied by the provision of essential community facilities, such as adequate roads, community halls, child care centres and sewerage reticulation. Secondly, our region includes a large number of underprivileged people. Unemployment is over 20 per cent, which is nearly twice the Stat7average. In the northern Sydney region of the New South Wales Department of Education, which extends from Sydney Harbour Bridge to the northern boundary of my electorate, 11 schools are considered to be disadvantaged under the assisted schools progra,m. Everyone of those schools is on the central coast and eight are within the electorate of Dobell. The social consequences of this region's deprivation is illustrated by the following two examples: Firstly, Wyong shire has the greatest number of individual juvenile cases in the north-east Sydney region. In 1980, 18 per cent of the total number of juvenile cases involved children from Wyong shire-I repeat 18 per centyet the shire's population is only 8 per cent of the region's population. Secondly, the percentage of people separated, divorced or widowed in Wyong shire at the time of the 1981 census was 12.6 per cent-l t times the New South Wales average. Local councils within the electorate of Dobell cannot continue to increase revenue by raising rates without severely penalising many people on low incomes. I represent an area where, for the reason I have explained previously, local government has been unable to provide the services and facilities 'for which it is responsible. Local govern,ment in my electorate is in desperate need of increased funding. In my opinion, the national government has a responsibility to increase funding to local government in developing areas. On 28 May 1979, the Commonwealth Grants Commission presented the then Minister for Administrative Services, the Hon. John MCLeay, with a special report on financial assistance for Local government. This report presented the Fraser Government with five options, including a proposal to allocate funding to local government on the basis of need. The Grants Commission recommended that the Government determine, as a matter of policy, which of the options it wished the Commission to adopt. As in so many areas of government administration, the Liberals refused to make a decision. I admit that sometimes Australia was better off when the Fraser Government could not make a decision. Take, for example, its decision on the national sewerage program. This program was established by the Whitlam Government. In the three Whitlam Budgets this program received $28m, $117m and $112m. After the election of the Liberal-Country Party Government in 1975, funding for the national sewerage program was slashed to $48m in 1976 and in 1977 it was terminated. If this program had continued, many thousands of my constituents would now be living in sewered homes. I note with satisfaction that this Government has established a national inquiry into local government finance to examine the matters which I' have raised. I commend the Government and the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) for ensuring that the views of local government, community organisations and individuals are being heard by this inquiry. I can assure the House that I will be very interested in the inquiry's progress in future months. It is'my hope and that of many of my constituents,that the end result will be a fairer distribution of Federal funds to local government. I turn to the New South Wales doctors' dispute and the impact it is having on the central coast of New South Wales. In the week before the election last December an anonymous group of doctors placed advertisements in local newspapers seeking to discredit me and my colleague the honourable member for Robertson by claiming that we were nationalising medicine. I quote from an interview with one, of the anonymous doctors which was published in the Gosford Star, which I am sure all honourable members read-I am sure the .honourable member for Robertson does-on Friday, 30 November 1984: Doctors admitted their resignations this weekthis is the week before the Federal !:lectionwere a final attempt to discredit the Government and emphasise their stand in the eyes of the public before the election. As one prominent specialist stated 'I am ruined on Saturday iUhe Government is returned'. Explaining the Government's attempts to rationalise the health system by stealth through Medicare, another specialist commented, 'they're really just communists out and out'. 'Their actions are based on the writings of Lenin'. I think even the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) would not make such a ludicrous claim. These doctors, who obviously hold extreme right wing views, were simply trying to create fear amongst the people of the central coast. They were acting as the political operatives of the Liberal Party. As I explained earlier to the House, my electorate has one of the highest proportions of pensioner constituents. I now wish to read to the House a letter which one doctor is currently circulating to people in my electorate. It is entitled 'Notice to all Patients' and states: The Bureaucratic machine is on the move. Investigators from the Minister of Health's department are on the prowl in this Gosford district at present. I have already been contacted by a patient who has been upset by their interrogation and felt she could not sleep until I assured her there was nothing to worry about. Another patient is very angry at the prying attitude of the interrogators, and intends to protest to the Prime Minister. I, personally, have nothing to hide, but I strongly resent the government's henchmen upsetting my patients with their visits and questions. If you agree with me, why not make a fuss about it? I can do nothing more than let you know what is going on, and hope that you will carry the baton from here on. Unless you do, believe me, things will get much worse for you, the patient. I have worked in a socialistic, nationalised medical scheme, and I know what I'm talking about. When someone seeks to gain political milage in this way by scaring pensioners and other patients, I believe he is beneath contempt. I wish to make it clear that the vast majority of doctors are not participating in this campaign, which is being organised by the radical specialists who seek to discredit and destroy Medicare. This campaign and the endless series of settlement negotiations have now reached their seventh month. Each time settlement has appeared close the radical surgeons, led by Dr Shepherd and Dr Aroney, have sabotaged the discussions. The truth is these people will not allow the dispute to be settled until Medicare is destroyed. The truth is these people are prepared to allow innocent patients to endure suffering and pain until Medicare is destroyed. I am amazed that the Liberal Party, through the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and its former spokesman on health, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), is now supporting the radical surgeons. This places the Federal Liberal Party at odds with its New South Wales leader, who recently called for all parties to resume negotiations. This dispute will be resolved only when all parties are willing to compromise. On 20 January the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) offered concessions to the doctors. I understand that the Australian Medical Association will meet the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) later today for further discussions. The only two groups not prepared to seek a settlement are the radical surgeons and the Federal Liberal Party. Before I conclude my remarks today, I draw the House's attention to an agreement signed last Sunday by the Victorian Premier, John Cain, the South Australian Premier, John Bannon, and the New South Wales Premier, Neville Wran. This historic memorandum will result in the construction of a $155m link between the Victorian and New South Wales electricity grid and the South Australian electricity power supply. Before becoming a member of this House I worked for many years as an electrical engineer with the Electricity Commission of New South Wales, and I would like to explain why this is a project of major significance. For many years New South Wales and Victoria have interchange<;l significant amounts of power through the Snowy Mountains scheme. When the three-State power grid project is completed Victoria, South Australia and New South Wales will be able to interchange power. This will provide industrial and domestic consumers in those three States, especially Victoria, with a more secure and stable electricity supply. At various times each State electricity authority will be able to reduce its costs of production by importing cheaper power. Gas turbine plants, which produce very expensive power and consume our relatively scarce hydrocarbon resources, will be used less frequently. I understand that the project will save consumers $14m every year. The historic agreement signed last Sunday by Premiers Cain, Wran and Bannon demonstrates what can be done when Labor leaders work together to build Ii better Australia. Mr Speaker, I wholeheartedly support the second Hawke Government's program, as outlined in the Governor General's Speech. The Government's program seeks to encourage all citizens to work together to build a better Australia. I thank the House for extending to me the courtesy of being heard in silence.

Title: PETITIONS
text: Order! Before I caIl the honourable member for the Northern Territory, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

Speaker: Mr EVERINGHAM
Title: PETITIONS
text: Mr Speaker, please accept my congratulations on your election to your high office. I certainly agree with the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) that a lot more money was needed for sewerage while the Whitlam Government was around. This Government, in outlining its programs for the next three years, speaks today of creating a stronger, fairer and more equitable Australian society. This commitment is of particular interest to the people I seek to represent both in the electorate of the Northern Territory and in my broader shadow ministerial responsibilities for local government and northern development. That is because the Territory electorate, the local government arena and all of northern Australia must rely upon the vision of the Government, to a considerable extent, for their sustenance and progress. Indeed, with the current media fad for naming members of this Parliament after their favourite occupations, I might be known as the member for the least influential. Certainly I would prefer that tag to the one of member for those under the influence, although that is how my areas of electoral and portfolio responsibilities might be seen. More than most other Australians, those in the Northern Territory, local government and all of northern Australia are under the influence of decisions taken at the Federal level. The words 'creating a stronger, fairer and more equitable Australian society' are nice words and sound great. But does the reality match the rhetoric? I must say at the outset that I am not greatly encouraged by these words, despite, or perhaps because of, the familiar ring that they contain. I am not encouraged because-let us face it-they were practically the only words in the Governor General's Speech on which we can hang our hats. There were precious few mentions of local government or of the north, although once again we are to be the guinea pigs. Cash up front for exploration licences is to get its Australian premiere in the waters to our north. Honourable members will expect me to speak at length on the Northern Territory and I will not disappoint them, but, first, I shall deal briefly with the problems of local government. We are all familiar with local government. We tend to take it for granted. But the third tier of government deals with grass-roots problems, and with increasing pressures on its services and severe limitations on its revenue raising potential, local government is clearly headed for greater difficulties; As someone said at a recent local government conference, the Commonwealth Government has the money, the State governments have the power and local government has the problems. These problems cannot be solved by the Commonwealth alone. The States must be involved. My few short years in local government taught me that there are no easy solutions and it will take me some time to come to grips with those proble,ms. But we will all certainly have to ensure that we do come to grips with them, or we will risk th¥. wrath of the electorate at the grass-roots level. I will be keeping a close eye on the work of the new Department of Community Services which has been given a brief to ensure that services are equitably distributed and better co-ordinated with those of the States, local government and community groups. Let us hope that this will not turn out to be just another departmental exercise in viewing grass-roots problems. from on high, or a power grab by empire-building bureaucrats. Turning now to my northern responsibilities, I recall the words of Prime Minister Alfred Deakin, who in 1904 asked Federal Parliament whether it was 'prepared to confess our incapacity to cope with the development of one half of Australia' north of a line from the Gascoyne River to Gladstone. I do not know whether the Parliament ever collectively made such a confession, but I do know that there are some three million square kilometres of northern Australia in which a little, under 800,000 Australians live. That is about 48 per cent of our continent" containing about 5 per cent of our population, which seems to me to answer MrDeakin's question. But there is ,hope. The Government now speaks of a more equitable Australia. That principle must apply .on a geographic as well as a socio-economic basis. We hear through the media that even the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) now sees the need for a railway to link north and south, if only to carry Federal funds to the Northern Territory. Last year in Adelaide the Special Minister of State (Mr Young), under some election pressure, I might add, said that the railway would eventually be built-no doubt recalling the promises given to South Australia and the Northern Territory by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister  year, shortly before the 1983 election. It is true that they broke their promises, claiming that an unexpected deficit made the necessary expenditure impossible. Of course, the completion date could have been deferred beyond the projected 1988, to make allowance for the deficit, but that may have been too simple. Instead, the Government got Mr Hill of the State Rail Authority to invent a unique and incomprehensible methodology which, he said, made the railway not viable. The Minister for Transport is so proud of Mr Hill's methodology that he refused to release it to us under the Freedom of Information Act. The Government ignores the fact that the unques c tionably independent Canadian Pacific Railway disagrees with it, that the Institute of Defence Studies recommends the project as a top defence priority and that the Department of the Arts, Heritage and Environment has recommended that, on social grounds, the railway should be built. Let us ignore altogether the Australian Labor Party's social audit approach to tranl'port infrastructure. Of course, Australian governments have been promising the railway since 1910 so perhaps northern Australians might be forgiven for questioning the sincerity of this Government's commitment to a more equitable Australia. Previous Labor governments did have a vision which, although we may not have agreed with it, did at least encompass all of Australia-although they also had Rex Patterson-while this Government seems to have little real interest in or sympathy with northern aspirations. Perhaps that is not so surprising as it has no Minister from further north than Ipswich. Certainly, the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) and the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) seem to be among the castrati of the fourth grade. It is just another example of the lack of influence of which I have spoken. Let us contrast the Governor General's Speech, which really only mentioned the north to tax it, with the 1982 ALP policy document 'North Queensland-Future Directions'. Of course, those were vote-grabbing days. I will cite some initiatives from that document: Domestic passengers to be able to use the Townsville international terminal. Air fare reductions through 'no frills' services. Upgrading and increased local control of regional broadcasting. . An Inter-State Commission to ensure more equitable-there is that phrase againtransport costs. Increased defence commitment to north Queensland, including five patrol boats to be built at Cairns. Cut out sales tax on freight. Sugar industry assistance. There are a whole lot more. These initiatives are a reflection of north Queensland's problems. But today, it seems, the Government hopes that they will just go away. Of course, they will not. As for creating employment, so far 300 people have been laid off because of the failure to keep the promise on building patrol boats in Cairns. Let us look at the sugar industry. Six hundred growers are likely to have to leave the industry and whole districts along the Queensland coast are dependent on it for their economic survival. In 1982, in 1983 and in 1984 this Government promised to give assistance to the industry, but to date absolutely nothing has been forthcoming. I can tell honourable members, from my recent visit to the area, that the growers in north Queensland are desperate. Why do not Government members go north and tell the people up there about a stronger, fairer and more equitable Australia? We should pity the poor tobacco growers. I know it is not fashionable to talk about tobacco today, unless to sneer. But we are talking about equity and we are all agreed that we hold with that. We should spare a thought for the tobacco growers who are facing increasing pressure to become more competitive in what has always been a back-breaking family enterprise. Growers understand the need to be competitive but, first, they would like a more equitable share of the price of a packet of cigarettes. A packet of smokes costs up to $2, of which the grower receives a lousy 4c. From tobacco sales Australian tobacco growers receive about $70m while governments receive in excess of $1 billion in tax on tobacco products. Is that equity? So far it seems that the Government's commitment to equity does not stand up to closer scrutiny and nor do the Government's policies seem to assist a stronger Australia. The north relies heavily on citizen forces for the defence of our coastline. The men and women who volunteer are often professional and technical experts who draw good salaries in their own right. Men and women of this calibre are required for the north-west mobile force-one of the most effective units we have-which operates from Arnhem Land to the Pilbara. But at the last Budget the Government decided to make our reservists pay tax on half of their Army pay. The result has been disastrous because the Government's decision has pushed them into the highest tax bracket. Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PETITIONS
text: Order! Before I call the honourable member for Chifley, I remind the . House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech. I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.  offer you my congratulations on your re;-election to your high office. I wish also to be assoCiated with congratulations to the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child) on her election as Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees. I 'also thank you, Mr Speaker, and the Chairman of Committees, for the kindness and courtesy shown to me as a new member on the Government side. Indeed, that courtesy was shown to all new members on both Government and Opposition sides. !trust that I should not be disorderly if! say how pleased I was, as were a large number of Government members, to see a lady Serjeant-atArms at the opening of this Parliament. I am sure that many young women in my electorate will be inspired to aspire to positions which might otherwise be seen as male preserves. I stand before my peers as the third member for Chifley. I thank my predecessors, John Armitage and the honourable member for Greenway (Mr Gorman), for the way in which they administered the electorate. I record my appreciation for the tremendous public support I received on election day and subsequently. It was a ringing endorsement of the Hawke Government's policies as they affect western Sydney in general and Chifley in particular. I pay a special tribute to my wife, Robyn, and my children, Michelle, Stephanie, Benjamin and Courtney, who have endured much and have never wavered in their support and encou-agement. It is as much a win for my family as it is for me. Victory in Chifley on 1 December largely reflected the tremendous dedication and commitment of the members of the Australian Labor Party who worked tirelessly throughout what was its contribution to the national one of the longest campaigns on record. Organisationally, it was difficult for the Party to reform the Federal Electorate Council, hold a quick-fire preselection and then organise and raise funds for the campaign. However, the Party responded magnificently. I thank my friend and campaign director, Richard Amery, the State member for Riverstone and his Deputy, John Aqualina, the State member for Blacktown, the President of the FEC, Keith Squire, his executive and council, the seven branch campaign directors and all the branch members. When one mentions individuals one can run the risk of offending, those one omits. If I were properly to acknowledge those I would like to, or who merit it, I would run out of time. However, I mention two people. The first is Tony Johnston, the former State member for Riverstone-I was privileged to be his first campaign director some 13 years ago-and president of the State Electorate Council. I was pleased to be close to him and am indebted for the experience I gained. The other person is Alderman Sylvia Whilesmith, who has always been a very loyal and dedicated supporter and now is establishing her very own high credentials as the first ALP women alderman on Blacktown City Council and Chairperson of our Community Services Committee. The se&t of Chifley is situated in the western suburbs of Sydney, generally west of Parramatta and east of Penrith. It is the heartland of Labor's western stronghold. The heart of my electorate is Mount Druitt, where I am proud to say I live and where I have' insisted on opening my electorate office. The people of Bidwill, Blackett, Dharruk, Emerton, Hebersham, Lethbridge Park, Shalvey, Shane Park, Tregear, Whalan and Willmot have a special place in my heart. They are not only part of Chifley electorate but form the fifth ward of Bhicktown City Council. These good people are the ones who thrust me into public life some three years ago in a council by-election with 76 per cent of the vote. At the 1983 council elections I was returned from the No. 3 position on the ALP ticket by some 54 votes. Honourable members perhaps can appreciate my keen interest in seeking out those 54 voters. The other suburbs of my electorate are: Blacktown, Prospect, Doonside, Rooty Hill, Minchinbury, Colyton, St Clair and North St Marys. The electorate of Chifley is. cosmopolitan and multicultural and is dis-· tinguished by the large number of young people: and significant numbers of senior citizens. Its; distinctive feature is the number of people who) have moved or are moving into the electorate. This is the centenary year of two great Australian prime Ministers, two great Australians and two great leaders of the Australian Labor Party. I refer, of course, to John Curtin and Ben Chifley. I should like to say a little about Joseph Benedict Chifley. I cannot, of course, claim to have known him. Indeed, at the time of Ben Chifley assuming the prime ministership, I was taking a more substantial form than a' gleam in my mother's eye. However, as a young man I read Chifley's biography by Crisp and was deeply impressed by the example provided by Chifley. In this centenary year I fondly hope that some of my younger constituents will similarly be inspired. In October 1941, Labor assumed office under John Curtin and Chifley became Treasurer. Without a doubt he was Australia's greatest Treasurer, although I suspect that Chifley would demur to Scullin and Theodore. His achievements as Treasurer include the introduction of widow's pensions and unemployment, sickness and hospital benefits. Perhaps his greatest contribution as Treasurer was to marshal the financial resources of Australia to maximise Australia's contribution to the war effort at a time when the conservative parties, the precursors of the Liberal and National parties, had so badly betrayed the trust and faith placed in them. Chifley was also Minister for Post-war Reconstruction. He became Prime Minister on 13 July 1945, retaining the portfolio of Treasury as well. He led his party to victory in the .1946 election. The achievements of his Government include the beginning of the mass migration scheme and the establishment of the Snowy Mountains Hydro Electric Authority, Trans-Australia Airlines, the Stevedoring Industry Board and the Joint Coal Board, the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, the nationalisation of Qantas Airways Ltd and overseas telecommunications, and support for Indonesian independence from the Dutch. If I have one misgiving, perhaps those like me who remember 11 November 1975 would rather not have seen proportional voting introduced for the Senate. I congratulate my colleague, the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) and the Bathurst City Council on the centenary celebrations they have organised. I sincerely hope that Blacktown and Penrith councils will be able to organise celebrations on a lesser sca\e. Until recently, I was proud to be Deputy Mayor of the great city of Blacktown comprising some 200,000 people. I was very' proud that Blacktown was the first council in New South Wales to Introduce a system for the payment of rates in seven equal instalments. In its first year of operation the system secured a 50 per cent adoption rate, which is proof of its enormous popularity. With great respect, I suggest that the underlying a-sumptions behind the introduction of the scheme are applicable equally to State and Federal authorities. I was pleased to be involved in the establishment of the greening of the City of Blacktown committee. I' commend the work of that committee and the success it has achieved. Specifically, I mention one project, the Nurragingy Reserve. Indeed, I would be very proud to 'say that this was my idea. Unfortunately, it was not, However, I can say that I became a very enthusiastic advocate of the project, which captured my imagination. This area of approximately 90 hectares is to be developed as a bicentennial project from funds supplied by Blacktown City Council and both Federal and State governments. The reserve. will include 13 individual picnic areas where families can enjoy barbecues and outings, three group picnic areas which can be reserved for the exclusive use of clubs and organisations, natural bushland and an urbanfOJ:est, artificial lakes, gardens, walking trails, bicycle trails, carparks, public conveniences and maintenance yards. Some $2,182,028 has been allocated to the project with over$1.5m being provided under the Federal Government's community employment program. Some 166 persons have obtained employment on the project. . This Government, Blacktown City Council, the people of Chifley and those who are working on the project can be assured that we are providing a wonderful social asset which will be enjoyed by generations of Australians. I trust that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and Blacktown Council will provide an appropriate opening function. The Blacktown City Council, in consultation with the Dharruk Aboriginal Land Council, Blacktown' Historical Committee and the Blacktown Bicentenary Committee have officially named the area Nurragingy Reserve after one of Blacktown's best known historical figures. Nurragingy was a member of the local Aboriginal Dharruk tribe and was one of the first Aborigines to receive a land grant in his own right from the colonial government in approximately 1819. I believ- i- is appropriate that I should briefly mention the inf!J.mous record of the previous Liberal-National Party Government and the record of the first Hawke Labor Government. The Fraser Government was conceived in blood-the blood of the former leader of the Opposition, Sir Billy Snedden-and delivered in a dark cloud of deceit and duplicity which rent asunder long-standing conventions. Whilst continually blaming the' Whitlam Government, Fraser and his Liberal-National Party Government presided over an unprecedented period of confrontation, when Australian was pitted against Australian, an unprecedented period of economic stagnation and mismanagement. The rewards went to the privileged few and the brunt was borne by the many,' particularly the disadvantaged in our society. Nothing became Malcolm Fraser nor humanised him more than the news of his humiliating defeat. The natiol) rejoiced. Bob Hawke had promised national reconstruction and reconciliation. I sincerely believe that if one had taken a poll of Federal parliamentary members of the ALP at the time they would not have predicted the outstanding success achieved on the economic front in a short '21 months in office. Confrontation and division were replaced by consensus. This Hawke Government has consulted widely. It not only governs with the support of the trade union movement but also with that of the business community. The results have been dramatic. Double-digit inflation has been halved. A negative growth economy has been replaced by one of the fastest growing economies of the free world. Banking is being deregulated. The Government is poised to embark on' reform of the taxation system. This taxation mess largely has been the legacy of successive Liberal-National Party governments in 30 of the previous 35 years. It is the ordinary men and women' of Australia, through the pay-as-you-earn system, who carry an unfair burden of taxation because they do not have the opportunity to minimise their taxation. This reform will be achieved without increasing the overall incidence of taxation. I welcome it and regret that former Liberal-National Party governments continually spoke up about reform but never did anything about it. We are privileged in Chifley to have many young Australians. I am deeply committed to the' concept of equality of opportunity for them and fot all Australians. We have many fine schools and facilities in Chifley. However, I do not necessarily believe that this guarantees equality of education. I am dissatisfied with the low participation rates of our students in the last two years of high school. I do not presently have the answers, but I believe the role of teachers is not merely to possess expert knowledge but to have the real ability to reach out to· students, to communicate that knowledge and to instil an interest, enthusiasm and understanding for the subject. Teaching is an interesting area. It is the only area where the inputs-the students rather than the teachersare blamed for the outputs. Nevertheless, I recognise that there are many dedicated, teachers in Chifley and I look forward to meeting them and discussing solutions. I am determined to achieve results. It was a pity that the State Government's proposals for a senior high school at Whalan were torpedoed. The John Pau1.11 High School stands as a shining example of what cal). be achieved in the west. . Equality of opportunity for employment is a major issue within the electorate of Chifley. I take pride in this Government's distinguished record of economic management and job creation, but I am far from satisfied. Unemployment arid rising interest rates with their effect on mortgage repayments tear at the social fabric of our community. It is the unemployed who are the victims, not the villains. I have many people in my electorate who are desperately seeking work. I seek jobs, jobs and more jobs for my electora.te. I believe that the Federal, State and local governments have an historic opportunity to transform the w-tern suburbs into the industrial heartland of Sydney. I hope to be at the forefront of seizing that opportunity. The Minister for Industry, Commerce and Technology (Senator Button) has, for the fir-t time, sought to heed the numerous' reports on manufacturing industry and has started to rationalise and restructure industry. Once again we had the situation, particularly in the, 1960s and late 1970s, where the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia in government did absolutely nothing, providing years of wasted opportunity. I have confidence in Australian invention,innovation and the skills of our work force. I believe that government direction and assistance is required to provide growth and more jobs for manufacturing industries. I suspect that neither serendipity nor market forces will generate the growth that we need. We need not only to cut out jobs but also to create them. I look forward to making an input into the Caucus infrastructure committee. ' I am an optimist, but even the most optimistic prediction still leaves us a long way short of full employment-indeed, we are unlikely to return to it for some time. It has been rightly said that the accord is central to the Government's management of the economy. In many ,ways the accord represents what the trade union movement is prepared to forgo for itself for the greater opportunities of the unemployed. I welcome that sacrifice and commitment. However, as a society we must realistically face up the issue of long term unemployment. As I said before, the unemployed are the victims, not the villains. I hope that the Government has the opportunity to review the unemployment benefit ,with a view to further increasing it. As a society, we m:edto rethink our attitudes to work. I do not think that the traditional view of a job being 35 or 40 hours a week will survive. I should like to thank the senior citizens clubs of Mount Druitt, Rooty Hill, Doonside and Blacktown. I was thrilled to be invited to their functions and I appreciated the warmth of their hospitality and friendship. It was, nevertheless, quite disgusting during the election campaign to witness the distress and trauma that these good people suffered as a result of the scare tactics adopted by the Opposition parties when discussing the assets test. These are the people in our community who should be esteemed and supported rather than preyed upon. I am pleased to have been associated with the Mount Druitt, Hospital from its inception and have been pleased to serve as Deputy Chairman of the Board of Directors with His Lordship Bishop Murphy as Chairman. From the outset we have sought to treat the whole person and instil a team approach to the delivery. of services. Our most important committee of the b-ard is on patient care review. I must say that I abhor the current doctors' pute and was stunned that the Opposition should come out in support of the rebel specialists. What this dispute is all about is: Firstly, money; secondly, who should control the hospital system, be it doctor or state; and, thirdly, whether Medicare patients should have an equality of access to the best medical treatment. I could give many examples, but I shall give only one of where a doctor in surgery halted proceedings on the patient-a child-to ring up the parents from the operating theatre to determine whether the child was privately insured or a Medicare patient. I am concerned that there are many people in our community who need medical attention but because of the dispute they' are not getting it. There are children whose fractures will never be properly set; there are others waiting ,for the onslaught of another attack, with attendant pain and suffering, so that they may be classified as emergency cases. I regret that the ladies of Our Lady of Consolation Nursing Home and Doonside Nursing Home are being shuffled from one hospital to another. I cannot rule Qut the possibility that some may have died in the process. The attitude of these rebel specialists is callous and totally indifferent to individual dignity and needs. The whole community condemns them and their advocates, the Liberal Party. Mr Speaker, I sincerely look forward to the next three years and the opportunity to speak out on behalf of my constituents. I sincerely hope that I will live up to the trust and responsibility placed upon me'. I thank the House.

Speaker: Mr CONQUEST
Title: PETITIONS
text: Thank you, Mr Speaker, for drawing the attention of the House to the fact that this is my maiden speech. At the outset, I thank you, Mr Speaker, and Madam Deputy Speaker for the warm way in which you greeted the new members of this Parliament and for being such gracious hosts during the seminar that we had. As you said, Mr Speaker, I rise for the first time to address members of this Parliament. I am aware of the convention which suggests that a first speech by a member of this House should be heard without interruption. I am conscious of the fact that this is a courtesy that I will probably receive only once in this House. In such circumstances I will refrain from straying, as far as conscience dictates, on to matters which might be considered so political or so sensitive to disGovernment members that they might tempt some to respond through spontaneous reaction. That is not to say that at another time in this same forum I will not seek to draw reaction in the thrust and parry of political debate. While speeches in this House may be more savoury with a little salt, I seek today to tempt honourable members' attention, not with spicy oratorical flavour, but rather with the materialistic matters which briefly describe the new Federal division of Hinkler, a few of the problems being faced by constituents and a short resume of that great aviator who has been honoured in that naming. Hinkler is a provincial and rural coastal electorate in which the main centres of population are situated at Gladstone to the north and Bundaberg to the south. The division stretches from the coast westward across the Dawson River to the boundary of the Duaringa and Banana shires. Prior to redistribution by the electoral Commission, each of three Federal divisions partially serviced the present region. I speak, of course, of Kennedy in the west-represented by my good friend sitting beside me-Capricornia to the north and Wide Bay to the south. The honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) and the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) have continued their service in this House, whilst the former member for Capricornia chose to retire and has been succeeded by another. I thank those past custodians of what is now. encompassed in the new Hinkler division for their long and dedicated service to the people now enrolled in the new division. I look forward to co-operation with the three current representatives of Wide Bay, Maranoa and Capricornia in matters of common interest on our boundaries during the term of this Parliament. Whilst one member is not of the same political persuasion, I have known each person for a long time and some affinity has already been established even though, perhaps, in a more relaxed environment. The history of this House bears testimony to the fact that politics are not a barrier to friendship and respect, even though members may be philosophically divided. So should it be at all times. The Federal division of Hinkler is almost microcos,m of Australia, with a great diversity economic endeavour and social thinking. large aluminium processing industries and house complexes in and near Gladstone have brought a measure of stability to that city. the less, in the aftermath of massive development, we perceive the difficulties of transition as itinerant construction and technical workers leave in search of further employment. Small businesses have been closing with demoralising regularity, bringing further unemployment disruption to families. The social problems we perceive are not unique to Gladstone when compare the situation with other such growth citrus centres which have slowed down. It is vital for government to recognise, however, that such areas require special consideration and finance to lessen the impact of this demoralising reversal in the economy Just a short distance north of Gladstone lie some of the world's richest deposits of oil shale. Demands for this energy resource could escalate sooner than expected if, as aviation indicators suggest, the denser synthetic fuels can provide longer ranges in flight against an equivalent fuel load of fossil derivatives. The city of Bundaberg and the immediate district are also feeling the effects of the recession as the sugar farmers and the dependent industries within that infrastructure face a crisis of serious proportions. Decisions on the future of the sugar industry should place heavier reliance on the short term social problems so created, rather than economic philosophies devoid of compassion. Unfortunately, compassion is not a criterion by any dimension within the academic field of the economist. I remind honourable members that good government is first and foremost a people-orientated institution, and therein lies the purpose of its establishment. The region around Bundaberg has a viable fruit and vegetable industry which has the capacity to become the salad bowl for South East Asia and other countries. But as the sugar growers turn to these alternative crops to survive, there is a real danger of creating a glut on the domestic market, thus threatening the livelihood of the traditional small crop growers. Support for the continued viability of agricultural production throughout the division will be addressed vigorously by my office during future deliberations in this House. The conventions of this maiden speech preclude such action now, although, Mr Speaker, I am sorely tempted to be more outspoken. However, I ask all honourable members assembled here to recognise the important contribution that primary industry has made to the economy of Australia through a vital export income. It is noteworthy, though, to of consider that even in these distressing times just The one by-product of Bundaberg's sugar power production-a little drop probably known to many members of this House; I refer to a famous Neverrum-from one factory contributed over $50m to government revenue by way of excise and sales the tax in the last financial year. The income from agricultural production to successive governments has subsidised many projects of benefit to this nation, and the farmers' plea for assistance and now should not be so lightly discounted. The division of Hinkler is also a significant conwe tributor to the economy of Australia through fruits, grains, cotton, beef and other meats, tobacco and dairy products. All these are affected by cost increasing decisions of government. A vigorous export promotion campaign should be maintained with relentless zeal to secure stable markets against the heavily subsidised produce dumped on the international market by the European Community. No members of this House should countenance or support an import parity price philosophy for Australian primary production. Farmers, too, are entitled to a fair day's pay for a fair day's work. I have read the submissions to the Government by the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation calling for urgent action to restore confidence to the dairy industry. The proposals contained therein have the support of each State organisation. I join them in a call to government to take urgent action to alleviate the financial pressures on the member farmers. Milk is a basic food. The industry has continually argued that holding down dairy product prices could be counterproductive in respect of milk production. Faced with a decline in price, the farmers' first reaction is to increase production in order to maintain gross income and meet commitments. Milk production declines only after the dairy farming community exhausts its capacity to work harder and longer. When this point is reached, farmers leave the industry in great numbers and the resulting decline in production becomes excessive. It should be further noted that the prices of manufactured dairy products in Australia are relatively cheap in comparison with almost all Western countries. It is true to say that we can purchase many of our agricultural commodities more cheaply today on the international market; but if we allow those primary industries in Australia to be destroyed for consumer orientated expediency, who will guarantee continuity of supply? Who is prepared to guarantee that the price of imports will not increase substantially in the near future? Who will care for the people who have depended on farm income in the many towns the farmers now support? Who indeed? The people on the land have enough to contend with as they battle the elements of nature. Let us not now add indifference of government to the vagaries to which they are exposed. This nation's wealth and progress emerged from the sweat and tears of primary producers and therein still lies our future. Before we throw in the towel to signify the demise of those rural dustries now in serious trouble, let us at least offer a tissue of support and encourage them to go just one more round. They have the will and they have the courage. Let us givl(them interim financial support. The known mineral wealth of the Hinkler division is also significant to the economy. Large coal deposits are mined by Thiess Dampier Mitsui Coal Pty Ltd at the Moura and Kianga fields. The old Cracow goldfields are being reworked with new technology and equipment. Many other goldfields are being assessed as the potential to rework the old diggings is improving. Nearer the coast, at Biggenden, one of the few magnetite mines still operates successfully. Additional reserves of oil shale are located at Lowmead and Nagoorin near the coast and at Duaringa in the west. For those who like to go rock-hounding and fossicking, there are many fine gems to be found in the western shire of Banana. The offshore waters of the Hinkler division also support a large fishing fleet which mainly utilises the facilities for berthing and processing at Gladstone and Bundaberg. The seafood delicacies from these fishing grounds are reriowned for the quality and variety of their selection. Yet, the fisherman too face the problems of increasing costs for services and fuels. There are indications also of dwindling stock resources caused by the incursion of large fishing vessels from other centres, and destructive influences affecting traditional fish breeding environments. The coastal areas and offshore islands in the Hinkler division combined with the historically rich hinterland could be the mecca for increased tourist traffic. There are numerous well established resorts along the coast and on the islands of the Great Barrier Reef. The many small inland towns offer an old world hospitality which complements the charm of the various localities. Off the beaten track, the adventurous traveller will find breathtaking views of the countryside and many splendid gorges. The residents of Gladstone are justifiably proud of the great natural harbour on which the city nestles and to which they flock for aquatic recreation. Although Port Bundaberg, at the mouth of the Burnett River, is not as well known as the major trading port of Gladstone, it is still a vital sugar, molasses and oil terminal. The Burnett River is also an important recreation facility for the district. Before concluding, it would be fitting if I were to dwell for a short period to recognise Squadron Leader Bert Hinkler, after whom the Federal division is named. This famous pioneer aviator was in- small in physical stature, but as Major Turner wrote in the London Daily Telegraph following Bert's tragic death: 'He was a small man with a giant's heart'. Herbert John Louis Hinkler, affectionately known as Bert, was born in Bundaberg on 8 December 1892. During his pioneer aviation days Bert Hinkler became the idol and hero of all Australians as they proudly sang the praises of HustlingHinkler, upin the sky. His principal feats were the first solo flight from Great Britain to Australia and the first solo flight across the South Atlantic Ocean from west to east. His flight across the South Atlantic was an admirable performance, but there is no doubt that the 16-day flight from England to Australia is one of the best remembered. Enduring extreme discomfort in a small Avro Avian, lacking ground and communication support, with primitive navigational aids, and with only an atlas map to guide him, Bert Hinkler displayed courage and determination. The last flight of this great Australian was another solo attempt from England to Australia. Tragically, he lost his life when he crashed in the Prato Magno Alps in Tuscany, Italy, on 8 January 1933. It is a fitting memorial to Bert Hinkler that the new Federal division of Hinkler has been so named. The holder of the Distinguished Service Medal for bravery in action over Germany in 1916 and the Air Force Cross presented for the finest aerial exploit of 1925, Squadron Leader Bert Hinkler was also presented with the International Aeronautical Federation gold medal in the same year. It is interesting to note that another nominee for the gold medal in the same year was Squadron Leader Charles Kingsford-Smith. Any person elected to represent the division of Hinkler would be hard-pressed to mirror the feats of this famous man, yet strength can be gained in striving to emulate those personal traits which he displayed. Bert Hinkler was not deterred by the formidable barriers he faced on the way to success. He set a true and faithful course towards his objective, with a determination to succeed against any adversity; fearless in thought, deed and action; believing in what he was doing and the eventual benefit to mankind. Yet Bert Hinkler was constantly humble amidst all the accolades bestowed on him by many nations. Reference to the life and success of Bert Hinkler surely places a heavy responsibility on this division's representatives to refrain from any action which could demean the name of Hinkler by association. Under such circumstances a representative can only draw strength if he too is not distracted from any course considered true in the navigation of matters political. lam honoured to be known as the member for Hinkler, which I understand, will be the only term used to recognise me in this House.
